How did Christian thinkers cope intellectually with the extraordinary changes in the political status of the early church? Was Aristotle an apologist for ancient slavery? Why and how did early modern thinkers draw on the inheritance of the ancients in debates over sovereignty and freedom? These are some of the important questions which this paper will enable you to explore, as you encounter some of the classic texts in the origin of Western political thought and come to understand the way that they expressed and engaged with the intellectual controversies and assumptions of their times.Like Paper 20/4, this paper offers two kinds of intellectual adventure. In Part A, you will focus on a close reading of major texts within political and intellectual contexts. This allows you to explore how philosophical argument and analysis emerges within an historical period and so to develop philosophical skills within the Historical Tripos (or Human, Social and Political Sciences Tripos for those borrowing this paper). In Part B, you will focus on groups of texts which are thematically and historically connected, developing your ability to understand the way that a given political language is inflected, used and challenged in specific historical circumstances. For those considering doing other papers in the history of political thought or who have done them, this paper will provide a crucial basis to enrich and deepen your understanding of the foundations of modern politics.Because the material to be covered is both diverse and especially challenging in that many students will not have studied the history of political thought before, more lectures are offered for this paper than for some others. This need not cause you alarm as you are not required or expected to attend them all since you will cover in supervision only 7 or 8 of the 30 named topics, and need answer in the examination only on 3. There is a convention that (at least) one examination question will be set on every named A and B topic. The result of all this is that you have the opportunity in conjunction with your supervisor to chart your own intellectual pathway through this paper. You may choose to concentrate entirely on ancient and medieval material, or on medieval and early modern, or to choose some other combination of thinkers and topics recommended by your supervisor.The Reading List is the invaluable guide and resource which lists all of the topics with specified primary reading and recommended secondary reading. This leaflet is to be read in conjunction with the Reading List and will help you select those lectures which will be most relevant to your chosen topics, as well as those which are closely related, since you will often benefit from attending lectures on topics closely related to your specific supervision topics as well. Note that lectures from other Faculties may be included in this list because the expertise in the history of political thought in Cambridge is shared among several Faculties.The lecturers will Paper 19 reading listPaper 19 course guide   Useful online resourcesPast Papers:Part IThe Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship Internal Competition 2018 is now open. web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at CambridgeConvenor:  Dr David PrattThis paper covers the political history of the British Isles from the late Roman period to the end of the 11th century, a period important for the emergence and development of kingdoms, royal and aristocratic power, ecclesiastical and administrative structures and law, and during which different groups of migrants and invaders from the European continent, Angles, Saxons and Jutes, Vikings and Normans, made their mark to varying degrees upon the political life of these islands.Although the main focus of the paper is upon developments within England, these are examined with particular reference to the interaction between the English and their Celtic neighbours to the North and West, and are compared and contrasted with developments in the exercise of power and patterns of government and law in what are now known as Wales, Scotland and Ireland (each of which may be studied in their own right as well), taking the wider continental context into consideration where appropriate.The earlier part of the paper considers the end of Roman rule in Britain, the problems of evidence in establishing the political history of the fifth and sixth centuries and, in particular, how Germanic invaders and migrants became politically and cultural dominant in lowland Britain. It examines the emergence of the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms and the shifting power relations between them, and compares structures and practices of kingship in England with those elsewhere in the British Isles, as well as the political impact of conversion to Christianity.The Viking invasions of the ninth century and their political consequences throughout the British Isles form a major theme, as does the expansion of the power of the kings of Wessex, their changing conception of their power, and the eventual conquest of all of England during the tenth century to create the first kingdom of the English, processes which may be compared and contrasted with contemporary developments elsewhere in the British Isles.The final part of the paper examines the consequences of two successive continental conquests of England during the eleventh century-by the Danes in 1016 and by the Normans in 1066, and also considers the impact of the latter in Wales and Scotland.The paper as a whole is marked by an emphasis upon the primary sources, both written (such as narrative histories, charters, laws) and material (such as coins), an understanding of which greatly enriches the experience of appreciating what was different as well as what we recognize as familiar in the early history of these islands.For the period before c.1066, the Anglo-Saxon England bibliography compiled by Professor S.D. Keynes is essential. For the period after 1050, see the booklist for Paper 3. For the history of Celtic Britain and Ireland, see the Bibliography for Papers 2 and 7.The lectures for the paper comprise a course of eight core lectures and a number of more specialized courses of lectures provided by both the History Faculty and early medievalists from the Department of Anglo-Saxon, Norse and Celtic (ASNC) and the Department of Archaeology. Because of the closely interconnected nature of political, religious, social and economic developments during the early medieval period, some of the lectures listed will be of relevance to both Papers 2 and 7. The course examines the early modern expansion of Spain and Portugal into the Caribbean, central and South America and the history of Atlantic slavery. It analyses the 'first age of global imperialism' between 1760 and 1830, when the European powers, and especially the British, began to establish territorial empires in Asia and Africa. It considers the economic, political and strategic reasons behind the Partition of Africa and the battle for concessions in the Far East in the late nineteenth century. But this is not simply a European-centred course. It also examines the indigenous civilisations, economies and states of the Americas, Africa and Asia in their own terms. The resistance and adaptation of non-European peoples to western economic penetration, political dominance and evangelisation occupies centre stage in lectures and supervisions. This paper concentrates on American beginnings, looking broadly at the diverse, violent, entangled, and enthralling worlds created by Native Americans, Europeans, and Africans in North America in the period. The ramifications of choices made in this period— in terms of cultural contact, labour, slavery, race, gender, politics, sexuality, war, and religion—remain with us still.  The paper tracks regional development across a broad range of American colonies and states, settled by the British, the Spanish, and the French, in mainland America as well as the Caribbean.  The critical importance of Native Americans, Africans, and African-Americans also receives attention.  The paper considers the origins, course, and outcomes of the American Revolution, as well as the ways in which all kinds of people influenced colonial, revolutionary, and national trajectories.  It also attends to specific moments of American confrontation and conflict, including its greatest such moment, the Civil War.  Lectures include discussion both of historical developments and of larger historiographical debates in this field, as well as on primary sources generated by the American experience.Paper 22 reading listPaper 22 Course GuideUseful online resources for Paper 22Past Papers:Part I  Convenor:  Dr Julia GuarneriThis paper examines the history of the United States from the end of the Civil War in 1865 to the present. The notion of a 'Third World' emerged very much as the legacy of these shaping influences, popularised in the debates of the 1960s and 1970s when the world's states and economies seemed to be very clearly divided between those of the advanced 'West' and the newly independent but still 'underdeveloped' Third World.More recently, social change and economic advance in many of the world's postcolonial societies, particularly in east and southeast Asia, suggest now that we need new and more complex ways of understanding what have become in the later C20, global flows of capital and people, commodities and technologies. In these contexts, labels such as 'Third World', even the 'postcolonial' world, may no longer seem meaningful descriptions of what is a more complex and multicentred global society. Yet these very forces of 'globalisation', with the free play they create for unprecedented convergences of capital, technology and resources, seem to raise again issues of power and marginalisation, dominance and exploitation. As the legacies of older forms of imperialism and nationalism seem to recede into the historical past, categories such as the 'Third World' and the 'postcolonial' world may still therefore serve as important pointers to the inequalities of wealth and power that characterise the modern world.Paper 23 reading listPaper 23 course guideUseful online resourcesPast Papers:Prelim (Paper 19)Part I The Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship Internal Competition 2018 is now open. Foreign policy and diplomatic and military history are aspects of this and are likely to play quite a large part in periods when England was linked to an overseas territory, notably in France, or at lengthy war with one.The other central component of the papers is the constitutional framework within which politics took place. This is understood as the formal structures of power (the institutions of monarchy, government and law, both local and national, including parliament), the more informal ones (the inter-relationship of the king and his politically significant subjects - usually landowners - and the political aspects of the relationships between greater and lesser landowners) and contemporary beliefs concerning these.The 'British' dimension consists mainly of study of England's relations with other parts of the British Isles, but there is likely to be a small number of questions on the internal affairs of other British realms.Certain areas overlap with Paper 8 and are distinguished in this paper by a political and governmental emphasis. Thus 'feudalism' and 'bastard feudalism' are treated as aspects of the structures of power and governance and of local politics and, with regard to the Church, the emphasis is on its relationship with the state. These distinctions are made explicit in the reading lists for Papers 3 and 8.A study of key sources, is especially important in the early part of the paper and of key constitutional documents, such as Magna Carta and the Deposition Articles of Richard II, in the later part.Paper 3 course guidePaper 3 reading listGlossaryUseful online resourcesPast exam papers:The Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship Internal Competition 2018 is now open. They executed one king, deposed another, and built a republic; they fought a war in three kingdoms in the seventeenth century, three more against the Dutch republic, and finally two major European wars with the Dutch republic against Louis XIV's France.The 'medieval' polity transformed itself into the 'modern' state, although how, why, and when this transformation happened are controversial questions. The Tudors declared themselves supreme heads and governors of the English Church next under God on earth, and the Protestant Reformation they sponsored destroyed ancient forms of worship and reinforced the coercive power of the state. And yet religion also became a resource for challenging royal authority; the close relationship between confessional faith, royal dynasty, and the acceptable - and unacceptable - exercise of political power arguably set the scene for the wars of the 1640s and 1650s, the upheavals of the 1670s and 1680s, and underpinned the collapse of the Jacobite cause in the eighteenth century.Paper 4 encourages students to challenge some of the familiar and conventional chronological dates and themes of the period: the end of 'medieval' government in 1485, for example, or the 'inevitable' rise of the English parliament. Lectures and supervisions will bring you face to face with some of the major historiographical agreements and disagreements of the period, and enable you to think independently about the historical formation of the kingdoms of Britain and Ireland. Historical themes and forces necessarily complement the chronological shape of the paper.Tripos questions often cut across reigns or narrow periods of time; you may, for example, be asked to write on the issue of 'state formation', the development of political ideologies, or the governance of the kingdoms' localities. A series of core lectures in Michaelmas represent an important foundation for the study of the paper; each lecture explores a theme, institution, or idea central to the shape of early modern Britain. The core lectures are complemented by other lecture series.The course of lectures aims to present coherent and concise introduction to the period, closely related to the examination paper (remember that all lecturers contribute questions to this), and attentive to the chronological shape and thematic pattern of the three centuries between 1485 and 1714. Diplomatic and imperial history are covered elsewhere in the Tripos (i.e. Papers 17, 18, and 21), but Britain’s European and world roles were also matters of intense debate in domestic politics. Moreover, they contributed to distinctive views about national identity (‘Englishness’) which are arguably crucial in understanding the appeal of some of the most charismatic political leaders and political traditions of the period.These two centuries also saw Britain establish itself as first the commercial market place, then the warehouse, and finally the workshop of the world, while throughout the period it acted as the world’s banker. These successive economic transformations impacted on politics as new commercial and then industrial elites arose to challenge the hegemony of the old aristocratic, monarchical, and clerical regimes.Economic developments also created the world’s first predominantly urban society, with attendant social problems (policing, housing, health, etc), all of which required political solutions and challenged traditional conceptions of the role of politics and the state. Such problems also generated – at least according to some historians – a growing sense of class consciousness and potential for social conflict, and present us with the difficulty of assessing how popular politics functioned and how political order was maintained.Finally, concern for the social order helps to explain why religious issues played an important part in politics throughout the period.Another salient theme arises from the political unions with Scotland (1707) and Ireland (1801), which not only created a United Kingdom state whose legitimacy was being called into serious question by 1886, when a government first introduced an Irish Home Rule Bill, but also precipitated debate on issues of British identity and nationality.   The Irish problem, in particular, presented British politicians with a set of fundamental challenges to their dominant assumptions about property, religion, local government, and empire.A final theme traces the way political life was immersed in wider intellectual and cultural contexts.  Broad developments in society created new opportunities for, and new media of, political communication and association. Political tactics and goals found expression in many literary and cultural forms. The aspirations of varying groups of men were reshaped as the habits of daily economic and social life evolved through commercialization, industrialization and urbanization. Likewise, women’s political capacities, disabilities, and ambitions fluctuated in relation to their changing circumstances. Notions of political capacity and citizenship were enriched by intellectual developments.   The role of religious ideas was often important in debates on these broader topics, while there was considerable controversy about the role that religious institutions should play in politics and the constitution.The Cambridge History Faculty has always been exceptionally strong in the history of ideas, and this has naturally affected the way in which political history is understood. Concepts relating to the constitution, the role of the state, and national identity play an important part in the paper, and emphasis is placed on underlying intellectual, cultural, religious, and linguistic developments.Candidates who have already studied this period at school should find this approach both novel and refreshing, while candidates who have not studied the period before may be reassured that they will not be at any disadvantage.In the essays you write on this paper you may well have to deal with relatively short periods, but you should always be prepared to relate your knowledge of such detailed events and processes to the wider themes of the paper. Paper 5 reading listPaper 5 course guideUseful online resourcesPast exam papers:PrelimsPart IThe Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship Internal Competition 2018 is now open. Conservative leaders continue to be dogged by the shadow of Margaret Thatcher, who herself had sought to free her party from its immediate, 'consensual', past. The Liberal Democrats ultimately found it necessary to keep the 'Liberal' label, despite the desire of the original pioneers of the SDP to 'break the mould' of British politics. Add to this the polemical power in recent years of 'Victorian values', 'appeasement', 'the Dunkirk spirit', 'the welfare state' and 'the winter of discontent', and the ongoing centrality of modern British history to political debate is clear. To study this period is therefore a licence for judicious iconoclasm. It involves a sceptical re-appraisal of many cherished assumptions about Britain's recent past, and in the process grounds for endless debate. The results may be surprising, even at times disconcerting, but is unlikely ever to be dull. Between 1880 and the end of the twentieth century, Britain experienced two world wars, the loss of its Empire and the exponential increase of its parliamentary electorate. All had profound political consequences, although these have not always been immediately obvious. The party system and much of the constitution remains in place, parliamentary democracy has survived the challenges of Fascism and Communism unscathed, and politicians have spent much of the previous hundred years congratulating their audience on the country's remarkable capacity to 'return to normal' in the aftermath of major crises.Many contemporary political controversies, such as devolution, Britain's relationship with Europe and the future of the House of Lords, have obvious parallels with late Victorian debates. Yet while continuity undoubtedly forms an important element of modern British political history, it would be wrong to obscure the fundamental changes that have occurred. Religion no longer assumes a central importance in determining political allegiance (with the partial exception of Northern Ireland), politicians now communicate with their audiences primarily through the filter of television and women outnumber men among the electorate.This paper provides a unique opportunity to contextualise this complex narrative of continuity and change, while affording students access to many of the new types of source material (primarily oral and audio-visual) that make the study of the twentieth century so distinctive.Paper 6 reading list and course guideUseful online resourcesPast exam papers:PrelimsPart IThe Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship Internal Competition 2018 is now open. It also assesses developments in agriculture, estate-management, trade and towns; the religious and intellectual achievements of the tenth-century monastic reform; clerical and lay literacy and the use of the written word, and finally, Domesday Book and the impact of the Norman Conquest upon the peoples, churches, economies and cultures of Britain.The paper offers the opportunity to look closely (sometimes at first hand) at written sources (documentary and literary) and material evidence (e.g. metal work, coinage, pottery, manuscripts), by exploiting the exceptionally rich resources of the museums and libraries of Cambridge.For the period before c.1066, see the Anglo-Saxon England bibliography compiled by Professor S.D. Teaching is organized thematically, rather than chronologically: each lectures deals with change over time for its subject. The class each Friday follows the topic of the Thursday lecture and is run in a seminar style to engage more closely with the historical arguments and with the original source material that historians use to draw their conclusions. The classes allow students acquire analytical skills as well as to clarify and deepen their understanding of the lecture. Each class outline and the source materials used will be available on camtools, but no advance reading is required: time will be allowed in class to examine the sources. There are also two series of four lectures in the Michaelmas term which address issues for both Paper 9 and Paper 10: one on agricultural change and one on environmental change.   Paper 9 reading listPaper 9 course guideUseful online resourcesPast exam papers:PrelimsPart IThe Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship Internal Competition 2018 is now open. This is the 'middle' paper of the three papers in the history of political thought but it should not on that account be overlooked. It is arguably the fulcrum on which an understanding of both the others depends.Like Paper 19, this paper offers two kinds of intellectual adventure. In Part A, you will focus on a close reading of major texts within their political and intellectual contexts. This allows you to explore how theoretical argument and analysis about politics emerges within a given historical period and so to develop philosophical skills within the Historical Tripos (or within the Politics Tripos for those borrowing this paper).In Part B, you will focus on particular debates and groups of texts which are thematically and historically connected, developing your ability to understand the way that a given political language is inflected in different ways according to different demands of circumstance and inclinations of intellectual temperament. For those considering doing other papers in the history of political thought or who have done them, this paper will provide a crucial basis to enrich and deepen your understanding of the foundations of modern politics.Because the material to be covered is diverse and especially challenging for many students who will not have studied the history of political thought before, more lectures are offered for this paper than for some others. You are not required or expected to attend them all since you will cover in supervision only seven or eight of the 30 named topics, and need answers only on three questions in the examination. In the examination paper one question will be set on every named A and B topic. You will therefore have the opportunity in conjunction with your supervisor to chart your own intellectual pathway through this paper.The course guide is to be read in conjunction with the Reading List, which is the invaluable guide and resource which lists all of the topics with specified primary reading and recommended secondary reading. The Reading List and will help you select those lectures which will be most relevant to your chosen topics, as well as those which are closely related. Note that a few lectures from other Faculties may be included in this list because the expertise in the history of political thought in Cambridge is shared among several Faculties.The lecturers will Paper 20 reading listPaper 20 course guideUseful online resourcesPast papers: Part IThe Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship Internal Competition 2018 is now open. He or she is a History undergraduate's most important contact, and will assign to each of them a specialist supervisor for each paper. In nearly all cases, undergraduates have supervisions for one paper in each term, and so change supervisors each term. Supervisions offer teaching that is very flexibly suited to individual needs and closely monitored by the college.While most supervisions take place weekly, usually on a one-to-one or one-to-two basis, some members of the Faculty combine weekly small group classes for which students prepare reading, with weekly shorter individual supervisions focusing on each student's essay. These involve a different style of study from the weekly essay. Teaching takes place in classes at regular intervals in the last two terms of the first year. Presentations by option teachers are held in the first teaching week of Michaelmas term, after which first year undergraduates are asked to choose their option.Options typically take a broad theme in comparative history (such as gender, race, Christianity or film) and investigate continuities and changes over time. Several options are based on a close reading of primary source material, and examine the problems involved in using such sources.Other options explore big themes over long periods of time; or there may be a combination of theme-based and source-based approaches. Some options may also involve the use of visual material. Those who have followed source-based courses at school will find these approaches quite familiar.Themes and Sources is a compulsory paper in Part I (Paper 1), and is assessed by means of a Long Essay (3000-5000 words) on one of a variety of set questions. This involves extensive individual research. It is set in May of the first year and submitted in January of the second year, so most of the work for it is done in the intervening vacations. Long essay questions will be available here on Thursday 24 May 2018 Information relating to Themes and Sources options taught 2016-2018 can be found here (Cambridge University only)  Themes and Sources Long Essay GuidanceFaculty Style GuideGuidance on plagiarismThemes and Sources Past Papers Long Essay cover sheets and declaration form (available Easter Term) © 2017 University of Cambridge

web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at Cambridge The body is at once the source of our most personal and individual experiences, and one of the principal ways in which we display our membership of a particular culture located in time and space. The paradox of the body is to be both timeless—the universal constant which is common to every body throughout history—and profoundly historicised. This course addresses the transformations in knowing, representing and possessing the body over a period beginning with the Renaissance reform of anatomy by Vesalius and his successors, and ending with the eugenic and Utopian projects of the early twentieth century. En route, it takes in the questions of bodily monstrosity as natural, political and scientific phenomenon; race, gender and class; social hygiene and physical culture. Past practices of normalising, regulating, training and quantifying the body are explored, as well as ways of inscribing and identifying it, from dress and photography to the creation of the labouring body.How should we approach the history of the body? Historians who have written about the body have drawn upon a wide range of related disciplines: anthropology, sociology, the history of science and medicine, art, gender studies, disability studies, queer theory and postmodernism. It is often those approaches which seem, on the face of it, to be the least concerned with the body as such which have generated the most fruitful and thought-provoking approaches to the body, and have allowed us to ‘get behind’ the apparently self-evident nature of the body as an historical object to reflections about symbolism, or about what underlies definitions of the ‘normal’, ‘healthy’, or ‘beautiful’ body. While bodies are material, they are also very much creations of a particular historical or geographical culture. Conventions for viewing, moulding and measuring the body vary greatly in time and place, as do the conventions governing gesture and dress. Power is frequently displayed via the body, and the conventions for doing so are likewise highly mutable. In the course we will explore some of these many roles that the body has possessed, and their significance. Should we speak of ‘the’ body or of bodies? What does it mean to have bodily standards and ideals to which individual bodies may aspire, or from which they differ? What are the boundaries between normality and abnormality, health and sickness, beauty and ugliness, power and weakness, and how have they been worked out in the past? And lastly, what is the relationship between the material reality of the body and its multiple symbolic roles?Course guide and reading list - currently in review© 2017 University of Cambridge

In Easter term, four sessions will be devoted to the close inspection of a specimen collection in each of four different types of institution in Cambridge. Students will be able to devote their long essays to the study of particular collections (not confined to those studied in class) or to themes linking collections. NB All classes in Lent term will be held in the Junior Parlour, Gonville and Caius College.  1.  Collecting:  History and Theory, 24 JanuaryStudents are asked to read Susan Pearce, On Collecting: An Investigation into Collecting in the European Tradition (1994) over the Christmas holiday.  2.  Collecting Art, 7 FebruaryD’Harcanville, ‘Preface’ in The Collection of Antiquities from the Cabinet of Sir WilliamHamilton  (1766), vol. 1, ii-xxiv, including dedication to George III. web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at CambridgeThis course investigates the experience of religious conversion as a fundamental part of the rise and expansion of colonialism on a global scale between the fifteenth and twentieth centuries. The first segment of the course will consider the concept of religious conversion as it has been analysed by historians and anthropologists, as well as the political and intellectual context surrounding the emergence of the missionary projects. However, the bulk of the course will be made up of case studies which will show the diverse reception these missionary movements encountered. The use of specific cases from Africa, Spanish America, the Middle East, and Asia, will require students to get to grips with deep cultural variety and the question of conceptual translation, as well as the political logic of European expansion.Students will be asked to consider the role of the ruling classes in the process of religious conversion, and why Christianisation efforts were successful in some regions (as in Spanish America) while having only modest effects in other areas (such as Asia). And we shall consider the different role played by the state in driving religious conversion in areas such as the Americas and the Ottoman Empire. The course has a theoretical component, which should stimulate students to take a critical approach to the historiography and develop their own perspective on issues such as religious boundaries, the state, and cultural change through sustained comparison. Yet it will also be rooted in particular moments of encounter as illuminated by a diverse range of primary sources. These sources will include chronicles, travel diaries, correspondence, sermons, reports of ecclesiastical visits, music, and images. Class 1 : The Concept of Conversion in History and the Social SciencesDr Gabriela RamosThis class will discuss historical and anthropological approaches to religion and the concept of conversion.Hefner, Morris and Vilaça (available on Camtools) are compulsory reading for this class.Asad, Talal, Genealogies of Religion: Discipline and Reasons of Power in Christianity and Islam, 1993, and ‘Comments on Conversion’ in Conversion to Modernities: The Globalization of Christianity, edited by Peter van der Veer, New York: Routledge. Bellah, Robert N.  ‘Religious Evolution’, American Sociological Review 29 (1964), 358-74.Berend, Nora (ed.) Christianity and Early Modern ColonialismIn this class we study the political and intellectual context of early modern colonialism, and its association with the spread of Christianity. We analyze the arguments advanced by the Catholic Church, theologians, missionaries and politicians to justify European expansion and the conquest and colonisation of the ‘New World’.Primary Sources:Alexander VI. Conversion in Southeast AsiaIntroduction: This class will explore the spread of Islam and Christianity to Southeast Asia during the early modern era. Religious diversity has often been seen as a defining characteristic of this region: both Islam and Christianity were brought to societies with Hindu-Buddhist as well as animist beliefs. Our examples will beAs both Islam and Christianity were introduced by foreign traders, it will be possible to take a comparative approach to early modern conversion. We will consider some of the political and economic motivations for rulers to convert, and how far Islam and Christianity penetrated into the various layers of social strata. We will also evaluate the extent to which the new religions changed social structures, promoting some groups and marginalising others, such as women in the Philippines. Here, it will also be possible to see how conversion strategies appropriated and accommodated indigenous religious beliefs, language and rituals. We will further examine how the sources examined here were used and understood in Europe, in particular how they fed arguments for increased colonial involvement in the region. Lastly, we will examine how the economic, social and political impact of conversion has been evaluated in the historiography of the region, with a special focus on the role of  religion in what has been called Southeast Asia’s ‘Age of Commerce’, a period of economic prosperity which lasted until the end of the seventeenth century.Questions for discussion:General introductory reading Sources Suggested further readingAndaya, Barbara Watson, ‘Religious developments in  Southeast Asia, c. 1500-1800’, in Nicholas Tarling (ed.), The Cambridge History of Southeast Asia, vol.  I (1999).Brown, C. Race, religious conversion, and colonialismThis class will examine the question of race in religious conversion in colonial contexts, drawing from a range of sources from the medieval and early-modern periods. It will begin by examining the sorts of ideas about difference and racialised difference that Europeans, and specifically Iberians, had developed by the end of the Middle Ages, which formed a conceptual framework that shaped their perception of the peoples they would encounter in their colonial expansion. The class will consider the factors that led early-modern Europeans to make radically different valuations of non-Europeans, using Jesuit reports on the people of Japan, India, and West Africa as a case study. It will then focus on the Spanish conceptualisation of the indigenous population of the Americas, and its significance in Spain’s colonial project. Finally, it will explore how such ideas were integral to the creation of an additional category in colonial society, that of the ‘mestizo’, and through it the significance of ideas of racial difference for religious conversion and colonialism.Secondary reading: Braude, Benjamin. ‘The Sons of Noah and the Construction of Ethnic and Geographical Identities in the Medieval and Early Modern Periods.’ The William and Mary Quarterly 54.1 (1997): 103-142. * Burns, Kathryn. ‘Unfixing Race.’ Rereading the Black Legend : The Discourses of Religious and Racial Difference in the Renaissance Empires. Andean and Mexican CatholicismAlthough there is enough evidence suggesting that the Spanish missionaries were quite successful throughout the New World, there has been much debate over how sincere was conversion among the indigenous people. At the heart of the question are the themes of adaptation and interpretation. Through the study of examples of colonial song, myth, and painting, this class will approach missionary strategies of conversion and indigenous adaptation of Catholicism in the Andes and Mexico.PrimaryAnonymous. Christian Conversion and Personal Sanctification in Colonial South Africa Many twentieth-century Africans committed themselves to a form of evangelical Christianity that taught conversion was only the first step of a life of faith. It was not enough merely to be baptized into the faith as a child, nor did one remain a life-long Christian through force of habit. Instead, many African Christians understood conversion to be a dynamic, ongoing act, necessitating the daily recommitment of the self to God, and in this way, resulting in a state of personal holiness also known as sanctification. An important example of this intentional commitment to a life-long journey towards personal holiness was the ‘Divine Healing’ movement in South Africa. Adherents eschewed medicine and doctors and instead proclaimed that bodily and spiritual health and sanctification should be sought in Christ the Healer. This class examines the origins of Divine Healing in the Anglophone world of the late nineteenth century, its circulation throughout imperial networks and its immense popularity in the Transvaal amongst Boers, Britons and Africans at the time of the South African War (1899-1902). The class will consider why recently colonized Boers and especially Africans were drawn to these Holiness techniques of self-improvement and self-purification. The class will examine how Africans’ cultivation of personal holiness through Divine Healing became a route to advance towards modernization, progress and Western-style civilization. Africans used conversion and its twin – sanctification – to lay claim to rights that colonial regimes were increasingly denying them amidst a period of hardening racial segregation.Primary SourcesSelected Extracts from Leaves of Healing (US-published Divine Healing periodical that circulated widely in the Transvaal, South Africa at the turn of the twentieth century) Selected Extracts from William Burton, When God Makes a Pastor: A Biography of Elias Letwaba (Victory Press, 1934) Selected Extracts from Gordon Lindsay, John G. Lake: Apostle to Africa (Christ for the Nations Publishing, 1972)Secondary (starred indicates recommended reading)*Joel Cabrita, ‘The People of Adam: Divine Healing and Racial Cosmopolitanism in the early twentieth-century Transvaal, South Africa’, Comparative Studies in Society and History (2015) – article is still forthcoming, but will be uploaded to CamTools James Campbell, Songs of Zion: The African Methodist Episcopal Church in the United States and South Africa (University of North Carolina Press, 1998) Heather D. Curtis, Faith in the Great Physician: Suffering and Divine Healing in American Culture, 1860-1900 (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007) *David Maxwell, ‘Historicizing Christian Independency: The Southern African Pentecostal Movement’, Journal of African History Vol. 40, No. 3 (1999): 243-264. For example, many practitioners were committed to a form of Anglo-Saxon ethnic chauvinism known as ‘British Israelism’ – what was this? What were the more progressive and cosmopolitan racial ideologies that also undergirded divine healing? What was the supposed link between a healthy body and a healthy race?2) What did Divine Healing mean for Boer adherents in the Transvaal, South Africa? What did the backdrop of the South African War (1899-1902) which pitted Boer against Briton mean for the success of Divine Healing in this period? How did Divine Healing provide a platform to articulate a new white South African identity, in which Boer and Briton were reconciled?3) How did the emergence of this white South African identity simultaneously exclude black South Africans from full citizenship? In this context of increasing racial segregation, why was Divine Healing so successful? For example, for black South Africans what were the progressive implications of Divine Healing? How did these techniques of bodily perfection promise full citizenship and equality within the British Empire? How did miraculous healing come to imply African modernity and progressive self-advancement? What were the other (possibly competing) idioms of African uplift and progress circulating in the Transvaal in this period?4) Where did Africans understand Divine Healing to sit in relation to their own existing healing therapies? How did Divine Healing transform existing local perceptions of health and sickness? How did its practices build upon and reprise indigenous healing repertoires? Class 8. Literacy and Conversion in AfricaThis class will examine the attitudes of nineteenth- and early twentieth-century Protestantmissionaries in Africa to the translation of religious texts, and the challenges they faced in translating key religious concepts into indigenous languages. What role did indigenous translators play in the translation process, and how does examining their role change our viewof the relationship between conversion and colonialism? But literacy acquired in the context of conversion did not only offer the potential for a new relationship with the sacred, it also provided a new means with which to engage in the colonial world. This class will alsotherefore consider how converts used their literacy both to work with colonialism, as clerks or elected chiefs, and to critique aspects of colonial rule.Primary Sources, Secondary Sources and QuestionsPrimary Sources:Salomo Nkya: ‘The story of my childhood’, in Klaus-Peter Kiesel, Kindheit und Bekehrung in Nord-Tanzania, University of Leipzig Papers on Africa, History and Culture Series No. 12 (2005), p. 128Extracts from British and Foreign Bible Society Archives: BFBS/BSA/E3/3/78 ChagaExtract from Mtui, Nine Notebooks of Chagga HistoryExtracts from: ‘The first year of the Chagga Mission’, Church Missionary Intelligencer, 1886Extract from W.J.W. The memory of the Nazi past has left a deep imprint on political culture in the two German states after 1945, and continues to inform politics, society and culture in reunified Germany. Tracing these debates thus provides a unique perspective on German identity and history after the war. Our course thus aims to analyze the often complex interrelationship between memory, politics and society. From the denazification policies of the Allies in the 1940s to the debates on the construction of a Holocaust memorial in the German capital in the 1990s this Themes and Sources option analyzes various attempts to come to terms with (or curb engagement with) the recent past. Such attempts were always part of a complex inner-German dynamic, as neither German state's attempt to come to terms with the past can be understood without the respective other. Core examples will be drawn from West German as well as East German material, in order to get a comprehensive picture and compare the development in East and West Germany.The Course Convener, Dr. Henning Grunwald, is DAAD Lecturer in Modern European History. He will be joined by Dr Helen Roche, an expert in the history of education in Nazi and postwar Germany in transnational perspective. Another focus will be on judicial efforts to deal with the NS past, from the Nuremberg trials to the recent proceedings against Oskar Groening, the ‘accountant of Auschwitz’.The course will be based on multimedia sources: Primary sources (documents, movies, visual material such as propaganda posters) will be in German, secondary reading in English. A prior knowledge of German is required for this course (AS or A level). An accompanying language course for this option will be offered by the language centre in the Lent and Easter term. Students with AS level will be offered a preparatory course in the Michaelmas Term before they join students with A level for the language course in the week prior to the Lent Term. For further information on the language course see: http://www.langcen.cam.ac.uk/culp/culp.php.Example documentsDenazification, democratisation, demilitarisation and decartelisation were essential aims of the Potsdam Agreement. This session will discuss the denazification policies of the Allied powers and the beginning of a new political life in occupied Germany after the End of World War II.Sources (25 pp)Reading (c. 100 pp)Additional ReadingAdditional Reading (German)Additional sourcesThis session will focus on the debate surrounding the question of individual and collective guilt and atonement. Fortunately there is nothing difficult or esoteric about the study of money in society, and there is no need to become an economic historian to do it.This option covers the period from the establishment of Barbarian kingdoms and the Byzantine Empire to the beginnings of the modern financial system, but a detailed knowledge of medieval or early modern history is not required. The course is concerned with money in its widest sense, including coinage, credit, commerce and banking.This course provides a rare opportunity for history students to engage with material culture, such as coins, as well as with more conventional primary and secondary sources. The classes are held at the Fitzwilliam Museum, which has one of the greatest collections of coins in the world, and there will be opportunities to see many coins and historical artefacts at first hand.Course website  [Access restricted to registered course participants only]Fitzwilliam Museum Department of Coins and Medals website Introductory reading:The Classes are as follows: LENT TERM 1. Introduction to Money and SocietyThe use of money is so universal in the modern world that it is easy to take it for granted, without much thought about how it works or where it came from. The growth of electronic means of payment and the decline of the use of cash in recent years has shown, however, that there is nothing immutable about the forms that money can take, and the recent global financial crisis has shown what can happen when money malfunctions.Until the invention of coinage in the seventh century BC, and in many parts of the world until recently, commodities of various kinds performed some of the functions of money as we now understand them. Commodities could be used as a means of exchange, to obtain other goods, and as a standard of value (for example, something could be worth a specified number of cattle). Some commodities (such as precious metal objects) could be used as a store of value, if they could be kept for long periods without deterioration or loss of value. Coins fulfilled all of these functions more conveniently than any form of commodity money, and their use was fundamental to the development of trade and state formation in the ancient and medieval worlds. The use of money took a further major leap forward with the spread of paper money and banking in the early modern period, laying the foundations for the financial system familiar to us today. 2. Coinage and currency in early medieval EuropeThis class focuses on the early Middle Ages (fifth to eleventh centuries), a period when the written sources relating to money and its use are sparse and can only be fully understood  with the support of the evidence of the surviving coinage and the archaeological record. While structuring our discussion around sources, we will be looking for answers to a range of general questions about money, such as: Where, when and by whom were coins struck? What was the purpose of coinage, and what incentives did the authorities have to issue it and the people have to use it? How much regulation was there over the production and distribution of coinage, and the subsequent use of it? Were old coins or foreign coins banned? Were there fluctuations in the amount of coinage in circulation, and what effect did this have on the way people carried out their transactions and on the economy generally? 3. Money, economy and Ideology in the Byzantine EmpireThis class will examine the connections between money, economy and ideology in the Byzantine Empire, focusing in particular on Byzantium’s seventh-century crisis, when the empire suffered major territorial contraction, caused by the Arab conquests, and large scale de-urbanisation. The extent to which a monetary economy survived this period of crisis will be examined through consideration of both numismatic and written sources. The iconography of the Byzantine coinage provides evidence of the religious and political ideology of the empire, but the class will show that it also became a focus of conflict with the rising power of Islam. 4. Merchants and money in Italy during the Commercial Revolution of the Middle AgesFrom the twelfth century onwards Italy experienced a period of radical innovation in trade and commerce that transformed the ways in which money was used. In the ‘Commercial Revolution’ the great merchant-banking companies of northern and central Italy established far-ranging networks, with headquarters in the home city and permanent branch offices in foreign cities, giving rise to the rapid expansion of long-distance international trade. Money could be transmitted across Europe by sending documents only and not coins, for the first time, and the Italians devised new ways to raise large sums of money to finance trade and government. At the same time, there were also major innovations in local banking. EASTER TERM 5. Money in medieval England I: The use of money in urban and rural society, c. 1086-1500In this class we shall investigate three themes. The first theme is the crucial role of money in the development of England’s urban economy, from the time of Domesday Book to the late medieval period. The second theme is the increasing use of money in the countryside. We will consider the role of commercialisation in the changes to be observed in the organization of life on the English rural manor. In Domesday Book the land yields a complex mixture of money rents, commodities and labour services. By the time of the Black Death rural life is increasingly dominated by the sale of produce and wage labour, to pay rents, manorial obligations converted to cash, and taxes. The third and final theme is the role of government. The sources show English medieval governments regulating the quality of the coinage, severely punishing mint officials blamed for making bad coins and taking measures against the import of foreign money. We will consider what effect these actions may have had upon the economy, and what they reveal about prevailing attitudes to money. 6. Money in medieval England II: Credit, debt and usuryIn medieval England the supply of coin was never sufficient to allow everyone to make all their payments immediately and in full. Also, in the middle ages as today, most merchants and households suffered from cash flow problems. These factors meant that almost everyone needed to borrow from time to time. Indeed, the economy depended on structures of credit. There were a number of different types of credit transaction, and this session explores the key types using primary sources. The sources reveal the activities of borrowers from different social groups, including rural landowners, townspeople, foreign and native merchants, and peasants. We also investigate the lenders in these credit transactions in town and countryside, devoting special attention to the Jews who acted as important creditors between the Norman conquest of 1066 and their expulsion from England in 1290. Lending and borrowing did not sit easily with medieval morality, however. In fact, lending at interest, or usury, was banned by the medieval church. The session also considers the reasons for the usury ban and its impact on commercial realities.One particularly important theme of this session concerns the relationship between the volume of credit and the supply of money. Through discussions of the period c.1100-c.1500, we will engage with the debate about whether the use of credit was ever able to make up for shortages of coin. We will also debate the pros and cons of heavy borrowing for economy and society, issues which remain as valid today as they were in the medieval period. 7. Early modern coins and creditThis class examines the strains put on the circulating gold and silver currency in the seventeenth century by an expanding market economy. We will explore currency shortages and the intractable problems associated with the coinage that was available, as well as the use of tokens in response to the need for small change. We will also consider the increasing use of credit and the question of trust in a society dependent upon credit. 8. The currency crisis of the 1690s and the Financial RevolutionIn this class we will examine the currency crisis of the mid 1690s, which resulted in the Great Recoinage of 1696, and the creation of the Bank of England, brought about by the cost of the war with France. The foundation of the Bank of England was crucial moment in the development of the modern financial system. We will also look at the some of the contending literature on banks published in the period, as well as ideas about state credit. © 2017 University of Cambridge

        The Raven web authentication system is provided and managed by University Information Services.© 2017 University of CambridgeFaculty of HistoryStudying at Cambridge OverviewThis Themes and Sources option explores how ideas of race, class and culture shaped societies and politics in nineteenth- and twentieth-century southern Africa.* It covers a chronological period from the colonial frontier wars in the nineteenth-century Cape Colony to the death of Nelson Mandela in 2013. We will grapple with the multiple ideological constructions of race and class, as well as notions of ‘culture’, and examine how these changed over time. Offering an introduction to the history of Southern Africa as well as to the global history of colonialism and comparative history more broadly, the course draws upon recent historiography that emphasises patterns of interconnectedness between countries in the region. Our particular interest is to explore and explain specific notions of race and class, as well as the complex ways they shaped state and society in southern Africa from colonial conquest through to the history of Apartheid and struggles for self-determination and freedom.* Southern Africa is defined as comprising the following countries: South Africa, Lesotho, Swaziland, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Malawi, Botswana, Namibia and Angola. Class 1: Race and ‘civilisation’: The Eastern Cape frontier and the Xhosa cattle killing (Dr Watson)The course begins in nineteenth-century South Africa. After the British seized administrative control of the Cape Colony from the Dutch in 1806, colonial conquest of the region was far from complete. Contestation was especially fierce on the eastern frontier where the British army engaged in a series of bitter wars against the Xhosa peoples. In 1855, an epidemic of lungsickness killed two-thirds of their cattle. Subsequently, a prophecy from a young girl, Nongqawuse, that the Xhosa should slaughter all their cattle and destroy all their grain so that the world could be renewed, gained particular potency. The result was that the political, cultural and economic integrity of the Xhosa, long penetrated and undermined by colonial pressure, finally collapsed.This class will examine some of the racial discourses that emerged from these events and how they intersected with British notions of ‘civilisation’. Using the memoirs of British soldiers, published colonial records, and the biography of Governor George Grey, we will address questions such as: what were the cultural ingredients of Grey’s ‘civilisation policy’? How were racist ideas of ‘barbarous natives’ used to justify imperial subjugation? What role did ideas about wage labour play? Class 2: Class, culture and labour on South Africa’s diamond mines and goldfields (Prof Dubow)South Africa was transformed by the discovery of diamonds and gold in the late-nineteenth century. African workers migrated to the mines for short-term employment from across the region, including present-day Mozambique and Lesotho. The mineowners took action to exert coercive control over their labour force and housed their workers in closed barracks, known as compounds, which they were only permitted to leave to go to work. In this way, workers were controlled and labour discipline and lower wages were ensured.This class seeks to explore ‘the world the mineowners made’ in late nineteenth-century South Africa, through examining how conceptions of race, class and culture influenced the making of the labour force. We will address questions such as: Why were African men, rather than women, the first to migrate? How did coercive controls such as the closed compound and pass laws develop? By what means was the racial bifurcation of the industrial labour forces achieved? What were the short- and long-term consequences of the mineral discoveries for African societies? Class 3: Race and imperialism in southwest Africa: The Herero genocide (Prof Dubow)German colonisation of southwest Africa (today Namibia) began in the late nineteenth century. Facing the loss of over a quarter of their lands, the Herero and Nama peoples launched an uprising in 1903, in which about a hundred colonists were killed. A large German army led by Lieutenant-General von Trotha brutally defeated the Herero/Nama combatants the following year. Subsequently, von Trotha gave orders that all captured Herero and Nama men should be executed, while women and children were to be driven into the desert. From 1905, remaining survivors were put in concentration camps, where they were forced to work as slave labour, and were also used for medical experiments.Today, these events are classified as one of the earliest cases of genocide in the twentieth century. Building on discussions in the first class, in this topic we examine the construction of racial discourses about ‘native peoples’ as well as ideas of benevolent imperialism. Questions to be explored include: how far was the German conquest of southwest Africa conceived in racial terms? What influence did the broader imperial context have on German colonial practices?  How did colonial authorities explain and understand ‘native resistance’? Class 4: Contesting cultures of race, sex and class in African settler societies (Dr Watson)Control over the mobility and sexuality of African men and women were key issues in early colonial settler society. Debating these issues involved the defence of white settler economic and social interests, as well as ideological constructions of race and gender. Focusing on the settler colonies of Southern and Northern Rhodesia (Zimbabwe and Zambia) and South Africa in the early twentieth century, this class will examine issues of sexuality and domesticity, and the construction of a moral order. How did the perceived sexual unruliness of African men threaten key material interests in settler colonies? Why was policy-making around issues of sexuality important to the processes of early colonial state formation? How was the ideal of white racial supremacy undermined by the reality of white poverty? Combining analysis of novels and documentary sources (such as the Southern Rhodesian Native Affairs Department annuals and the Carnegie Commission report on white poverty in South Africa), this class will examine these questions and the construction of a moral discourse in white settler societies in southern Africa. Class 5: African migration and urbanisation in southern Africa (Dr Watson)  The remarkable expansion of towns on the Northern Rhodesian Copperbelt from the 1920s became a benchmark for African urbanisation during colonial rule. African urban administration presented a particular dilemma to British colonial rulers. Africans had been understood as ‘tribal’ residents living under chiefly control in rural areas. Growing demand for labour meant that increasing numbers of African men and women were spending longer periods in urban environments. This class will examine the processes of migration and urbanisation in the British colonies of southern Africa, paying particular attention to cultural and class identities, using colonial government reports, oral histories and contemporary ethnographic studies. Historical understandings of ethnicity and tribe, culture and custom will also be explored. Anthropologists associated with the Rhodes-Livingstone Institute in Northern Rhodesia produced a series of pioneering studies on African urban life, from the mid-1930s to the 1960s. Their work covered issues from labour disputes and labour organisation, to the new habits, tastes and aspirations of urban men and women, as well as the emergence of new cultural phenomena, such as urban dance and burial societies. Although the Rhodes-Livingstone scholars were criticised for idealising ethnic groups, their studies were superbly observed and recorded, making for compelling source material. Class 6: Pass laws, group areas, and popular protest: Apartheid in urban South Africa (Dr Watson)The National Party won the 1948 election in South Africa on a platform of ‘apartheid’, meaning ‘apartness’. Apartheid developed earlier policies of segregation, but it was implemented on a much larger scale, and was supported by unprecedented levels of state repression. Numerous laws were passed during the 1950s, with the aim of enforcing a racially separate and unequal social order.This class examines two specific types of legislation: pass laws and the Group Areas Act. Pass laws had long been used to restrict the movement of black South Africans, but during the 1950s it became illegal for African men (and eventually, African women) to be in urban areas without a pass. These laws worked in tandem with the 1950 Group Areas Act, which enforced racial segregation in urban centres and also restricted the ownership and occupation of land to specific racial groups. To explore these developments, we will address questions such as: how far did popular protest undermine and effectively challenge apartheid laws? How should we judge the relative importance of race and class identities in understanding politics and society in South Africa during the 1950s? To what extent were South Africa’s African urban cultures destroyed by apartheid? Class 7: A luta continua (‘the struggle continues’): Liberation struggles in southern Africa (Dr Watson)By the late 1960s, the only non-independent African countries were those in settler-dominated southern Africa. Over the following decade, liberation struggles in Zimbabwe, Mozambique, and Angola escalated with armed conflict that spilled over the borders and impacted the entire region. Recently, new research has highlighted the interconnectedness and international dimensions of these liberation struggles, exploring the significance of the Cold War, the involvement of various former colonial powers, and their interaction with local political conflicts.This class presents a region-wide exploration of liberation movements in southern Africa from the 1960s until Zimbabwean independence, focusing on Mozambique, Zimbabwe and South Africa. We will examine the experiences of exile, and the role of international agencies in these movements, as well as the significance of local tensions in shaping liberation struggles on the ground. Key questions include: to what extent did liberation movements in southern Africa articulate a shared class and race consciousness? How did cultures of exile politics influence ideologies of liberation? How, and why, did peasants play such a crucial role? Class 8: Long walk to freedom: Reflecting on the life of Nelson Mandela (Prof Dubow)This class focuses on how personal stories can add to our understanding of historical events by critically reading Nelson Mandela’s autobiography Long Walk to Freedom. We will follow his development from ‘country boy’, to urban black South African, to ANC activist and political leader, to political prisoner, president and world icon. The extent of reverence accorded Mandela was particularly apparent at his death in December 2013, when the world engaged in an unprecedented exercise of collective mourning.By analysing Mandela’s subjective experience in the context of broader collective experiences in his lifetime, this concluding class draws together some of the key themes of this course. These include the impact of colonial conquest on rural life, politics and society in early twentieth-century South Africa, industrialisation and African urbanisation, the impact of apartheid on black South Africans and their resistance to it, and the growth of black militancy. Key questions include: In what ways was Mandela’s childhood ‘different’ from that of other black children in interwar South Africa? To what extent did Mandela and the ANC use their criminal trials as platforms for their political beliefs? How should we account for Mandela’s achievement of iconic status after his release from prison? Reading List© 2017 University of Cambridge

web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at CambridgeWhy is film so useful to the historian?  Film, particularly fiction film, provides information which conventional historical documents do not. Film is not a substitute for conventional historical documents but it is an extremely valuable addition.  Though more difficult at first to perceive, the benefits of studying the fiction film can be ultimately more rewarding for the historian than the more obvious information to be derived from contemporary newsreels and documentaries.  Fiction films rarely set out to document the events of their times but because they are designed to appeal to the widest possible section of the public, inevitably, even if unwittingly, fiction films tell future generations a great deal about the mores and customs of the time in which they are produced.D.W. Griffith’s The Birth of a Nation, a hugely successful and original telling of the story of the Civil War and Reconstruction, was released in February 1915 when the war in Europe was only six months old and still retained some novelty value.  It made the fortunes of Griffith, its producer and director and the film’s various distributors.  In 1917 Griffith made Intolerance, an equally original cinematic blockbuster but a commercial disaster because the film’s message of the horrors of war were not what the public wanted to hear in the year that the USA joined the war in Europe. Sometimes, a film’s failure can be just as useful to a historian as a film’s success.  A bad film can sometimes tell the historian more than a good film. This course is about Film and History, not film aesthetics. The popular feature films of the 1930s and 1940s drew vast audiences across the world, and as such can tell us as much about the hopes and fears of ordinary people as learned treatises by contemporaries claiming to speak on their behalf. Frank Capra’s films feature prominently in the classes on American history because they chimed so perfectly with the zeitgeist. Mainstream movies are designed to appeal to the largest audience possible so their commercial fate tells us how successfully they have captured the mood of the moment.  Capra’s Mr Deeds Goes to Town tells us things about America in 1936 that we can't get simply from a study of New Deal legislation.  If students want to know what America was really thinking during those fateful months between Hitler's invasion of Poland and the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor they should watch the 1940 adaptation of The Sea Hawk directed by Michael Curtiz in which direct parallels are clearly drawn between Elizabeth I and President Franklin D. Roosevelt, between England’s fight against Spain in 1588 and the Battle of Britain and between the Queen’s instinctive desire for peace and the flawed arguments of the Americans who believed in isolationism. They should also watch The Great Dictator and Sergeant York and A Yank in the RAF and Hitchcock's Foreign Correspondent. Certainly, they are "only" movies but it is a wise historian who opens his or her eyes and mind to the possibilities offered by the study of the fiction film.  Introductory Class 1 ~ Film history and Film as Historical Source 1895 - 1929 ~ Colin ShindlerMain film:  The Birth of a Nation (1915) The course is designed to teach undergraduates how to evaluate film as an historical source. It will therefore facilitate their understanding if they learn how the film industry started. The major technological innovations in the first years of the twentieth century took place in France, Russia, Great Britain, Italy and the United States. Films were rapidly exchanged between countries and new techniques instantly copied. Hollywood’s early establishment of its primacy in world markets was the result of the participation of the other developing film industries in the First World War. The effectiveness of wartime propaganda, however crude, was slow to develop but the astonishing impact of The Birth of a Nation confirmed its value.  Film was being taken seriously even in government circles as the crude propaganda films of 1914-1918 showed. The beginnings of vertical integration in the studio system in Hollywood shortly after the end of the war and the large capital investment it attracted maintained America’s domination abroad but each European country tried hard to institute its own native industry, making films about its own culture that Hollywood would never imitate. Other clips will include Civilisation, Battleship Potemkin, The Cabinet of Dr Caligari, The Big Parade, Metropolis, Sunrise, The Jazz Singer, Blackmail and the British government produced and financed documentary feature The Battle of the Somme. Required Class Reading:Geoffrey Nowell-Smith (ed.) The Oxford History of World Cinema (1996) Roberta Pearson, Transitional Cinema pp23-42Suggested ReadingAnthony Aldgate,  Cinema & History chapter 1  (1979)Tino Balio (ed)  The American Film Industry (revised edition) (1985)Gerben Bakker, Entertainment Industrialised: The Emergence of the International Film Industry 1890-1940 (2008)Kevin Brownlow, Behind the Mask of Innocence (1990)Kevin Brownlow, Hollywood :The Pioneers (1979)Gorham Kindem (ed) The International Movie Industry (2000)Richard Koszarski, An Evening’s Entertainment: The age of the silent feature picture 1915-1928 (1994)Geoffrey Nowell-Smith (ed.) The Oxford History of World Cinema (1996)Eric Rhode:  A History of World Cinema (1976)K.R.M. Short, Feature Films as History (1981)Paul Smith (ed.), The Historian and Film (1976)Melvyn Stokes: The Birth of a Nation  (2007)The course will consist of seven further classes on facets of Film as an historical source between 1929 and 1945.  The first three will be taught by the Course Convenor and American historian, Dr. Colin Shindler.   The sessions on Great Britain, Germany, France and Italy will be additionally assisted by four specialist historians whose research makes their understanding of the films of their country during the period 1929 – 1945 particularly helpful for students of this option.  Class 2 ~ Hollywood & the Great Depression 1929-1939 ~ Colin ShindlerMain film: Mr Deeds Goes to Town directed by Frank Capra (1936)From the time of the Wall Street crash until the inaugural address of Franklin Roosevelt in March 1933 America experienced a crisis of confidence unequalled in its history. Films likeI Am a Fugitive from a Chain Gang and Five Star Final paint a portrait of a corrupt and venal America and they were made in the major studios, which for the first time in their short dramatic existence with the exception of MGM, lost money heavily. It is hardly surprising then that Hollywood embraced the New Deal eagerly, welcoming the revival in national self-confidence and the consequent economic recovery because it was good for its own business. In films like Black Fury and Massacre they showed how the government planned to deal with miners’ conditions and the fate of ethnic minorities. Even musicals like Swing Time starring Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers and comedies like It Happened One Night are rooted in the Depression but all come with the mandatory happy ending. Ninety million Americans went to the movies each week in this decade. Film had a dramatic impact in a country in which only radio could compete for the attention of the mass audience.  The dictators knew the power of film.  The democracies were no less influenced by it.  Other clips include The Public Enemy, Scarface, Duck Soup, Gold Diggers of 1933, Wild Boys of the Road, Heroes for Sale, Gabriel over the White House Required Class Reading:Thomas Schatz, The Genius of the System : Hollywood filmmaking in the studio era (1998) pp. 159- 271Suggested Reading:Michael E. Parrish, Anxious Decades: America in Prosperity and Depression 1920-1941 (1992)David M. Kennedy, Freedom from Fear: The American People in Depression and War, 1929-1945 (1999)Colin Shindler, Hollywood in Crisis, 1929-1941 (1996)Joseph McBride, Frank Capra: The Catastrophe of Success 1996Anthony J Badger, The New Deal: The Depression Years 1933–1940 (2008)Morris Dickstein, Dancing in the Dark: A Cultural History of the Great Depression (2009)  Class 3 ~ Hollywood Goes To War, 1939 -1945 ~ Colin ShindlerMain film: Casablanca directed by Michael Curtiz (1942)It wasn’t just the American Communist Party that found Pearl Harbor healed the ideological splits. The battle between isolationists and interventionists had been intense and, because Hollywood was full of European refugees from fascism and political liberals, the interventionists held sway there to an extent that prompted an investigation by Congress during 1941. The unity in the country created by Pearl Harbor and the declaration of war was instant and Hollywood worked sympathetically with the government directives through the Bureau of Motion Pictures and the Office of War Information.  Movies, if it were possible, became even more important as the public lapped up the government propaganda that ranged from Warner Brothers’ dramatization of the pro-Soviet memoir of Ambassador Joseph E. Davies Mission to Moscow to Bing Crosby singing about the Four Freedoms in Holiday Inn. If Casablanca had been made before 7 December 1941 it is arguable that Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman would have gone off together but in a war the sacrifice made by the hero was important and of course that ending made the film memorable at the time and an enduring classic.   Nazis like Conrad Veidt’s Major Strasser made useful villains in many melodramas but the depiction of the Japanese in films like Destination Tokyo, Thirty Seconds over Tokyo and particularly The Purple Heart additionally showed an ugly racist edge which reflected the domestic treatment of the Japanese immigrants and their American-born children.  Other clips might include: Confessions of a Nazi Spy, The Sea Hawk, Sergeant York,, Guadalcanal Diary, Since You Went Away, Mrs Miniver and Sahara  Required Class Reading:Richard Raskin, Casablanca & US Foreign Policy in Film History vol.iv pp. 153-164Aljean Harmetz, Round Up the Usual Suspects: The Making of Casablanca – Bogart, Bergman and World War II (1993)  pp.102-116, 240-252Suggested Reading:John Morton Blum, V was for victory: politics and American culture during World War II (1976)Thomas Doherty, Projections of War: Hollywood, American Culture and WWII (1993)Robert Fyne, Long Ago and Far Away Hollywood Propaganda and WWII (2008)John W. Jeffries, Wartime America: the World War II home front (1996)David M Kennedy, Freedom from Fear: The American People in Depression and War, 1929-1945 (1999)Clayton Koppes & Gregory Black, Hollywood Goes to War (1987)Colin Shindler, Hollywood Goes to War (1979)David Welky, The Moguls and the Dictators: Hollywood and the coming of WWII (2008)John Whiteclay Chambers II & David Culbert  (eds.) World War II, film and history (1996)  Class 4 ~ Britain in the Thirties 1929-1939 ~ Colin Shindler & Lucy DelapMain Film: The Four Feathers directed by Zoltan Korda (1939)This class is designed to look both at British society in the decade leading up to the outbreak of war and its view of the rest of the world particularly through the trilogy of imperial films made by Alexander Korda – Sanders of the River, The Four Feathers and The Drum. The working class is notable mostly for either its invisibility or its portrayal as cheerful and spirited (Gracie Fields in Sing As We Go) or comic and incompetent  (George Formby in Off the Dole). The importance of America to the British film industry can be seen from the establishment by the major Hollywood studios of British outposts and the making of A Yank at Oxford and Goodbye Mr Chips as films with a British subject but with an MGM gloss.   Towards the end of the decade an awareness of events in Europe starts to become a significant theme in British films although Michael Powell’s The Spy in Black, like Curtiz’s The Sea Hawk dresses the modern story in a tale of times past, in his case the Great War. Hitchcock was quick to respond to the new mood in the country with the heroism of Michael Redgrave and Margaret Lockwood in The Lady Vanishes (1938), set in some nameless central European country, contrasting markedly with Cecil Parker’s pacifist coward. Margaret Lockwood appears again that same year as the star of Carol Reed’s Bank Holiday, a fascinating look at all levels of British society on a bank holiday weekend. Required Class Reading:James Chapman and Nicholas J.
