Laura Beers and Geraint Thomas (eds.), Brave new world : imperial and democratic nation building in Britain between the wars (particularly Mar Matera's chapter on the production of Sanders of the River   Class 5 ~ Britain Goes To War 1939 -1945 ~ Colin Shindler & Lucy DelapMain Film: Millions Like Us – Directed by Sidney Gilliat & Frank Launder (1943)Korda’s not entirely successful propaganda film The Lion Has Wings was released in cinemas barely two months after the declaration of war and thereafter Britain’s film industry was at the forefront of the propaganda battle. The triumph of Noel Coward and David Lean’s In Which We Serve (1942) which showcased the indomitable spirit of the Royal Navy was matched by Carol Reed’s superb The Way Ahead (1944), showing how the new British army took men of all classes and trained them to become a fighting force. Way to the Stars (1945), starring Michael Redgrave and John Mills, was Anthony Asquith’s realization of Terence Rattigan’s moving discourse on bereavement and the sacrifice of the American and Royal Air forces. The strength of the British film industry at this time was that it tackled all sorts of problems – the role of women in Leslie Howard’s The Gentle Sex (1943), the factory workers in Launder & Gilliatt’s Millions Like Us (1943), the danger of fifth columnists in Cavalcanti’s Went The Day Well? (1943).   The portrayal of Britain in Hollywood films of the time such as The White Cliffs of Dover (1943) and Mrs Miniver (1942) will also be of interest. Other clips might include Lady Hamilton, First of the Few, One of Our Aircraft is Missing, Life & Death of Colonel Blimp, Pimpernel Smith, A Canterbury Tale, Waterloo Road, Freedom RadioRequired Class Reading:A. Orwell, The Lion and the Unicorn: Socialism and the English Genius (1941)  Class 6 ~ Germany ~ Colin Shindler & Martin Ruehl [MML]Main Film: Titanic, directed by Herbert Selpin (1943)We start with the end of the glory days of UFA under the Weimar Republic – Siodmak’s People on Sunday and von Sternberg’s Die Blaue Engel  – before examining the ways in which Joseph Goebbels’s control of the German film industry became part of the Nazi party’s ideological campaign of Gleichschaltung. One of his problems was that some of the best film-makers, notably Lang, Dieterle, Siodmak, Zinnemann and Billy Wilder, had fled Germany. Of the directors who stayed behind, Leni Riefenstahl was probably the most accomplished. Her innovative techniques raised film as propaganda to a new level.  We will consider Riefenstahl’s artistic masterpieces Triumph of the Will (1935) and Olympia (1938), but our main focus will be on the more conventional Nazi propaganda films.  Contrasting the success of the costume drama Jew Süss (1940) with the pseudo-documentary The Eternal Jew (1940) will allow us to reflect on how Nazi ideology was incorporated into – and worked more effectively through – apparent “entertainment” films. That is why the main film that students are required to see before this session is Titanic (1943), the story of the disaster being utilised specifically to condemn the heartlessness of the British and to elevate the sole hero – a German whose warnings of impending doom were ignored. On a wider level it is instructive to see how different are the various film depictions of the 1912 disaster from this piece of anti-British wartime propaganda to the stiff upper lip hero played by Kenneth Moore in A Night to Remember (1958) to the last blockbuster version starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslett and directed by James Cameron in 1998.  Once again the fiction film tells us much more about the year in which the film is made than 1912, the year in which it is set. Required Class Reading:D. Welch, Propaganda and the German Cinema, 1933-1945 (Oxford 1983), ch. VII (‘The Image of the Enemy’), pp. 204-263.Suggested Reading:* S. Hake, German National Cinema (London 2002), ch. 3 (‘Third Reich Cinema’), pp. 59-86.* S. Sontag, ‘Fascinating Fascism’, in S. Sontag, Under the Sign of Saturn (1981), pp. 71-105.* R. Taylor, Film Propaganda: Soviet Russia and Nazi Germany, new edn (1998), chs 10-16.R. Etlin (ed.), Art, Culture and Media under the Third Reich (Chicago 2002), chs 4-6.S. Leiser, Nazi Cinema (1974).D.S. Hull, Film in the Third Reich (1969).  Class 7 ~ France ~ Colin Shindler & Robert Tombs Main Film: The Rules of the Game (La Règle du Jeu) (1939)The 1930s was a golden decade for French cinema, its most resplendent until the advent of the nouvelle vague at the end of the 1950s.  It played with the form in imaginative ways like Bunuel’s  Un Chien Andalou (1929) and  L’Age d’Or (1930) and Vigo’s Zero de Conduite (1933) and it produced the joyous early films of Rene Clair - Sous les toits de Paris(1929) Le Million (1930) and A Nous la Liberte (1931).  In the middle of the decade the politics of the Popular Front were reflected in Jean Renoir’s Le Crime de Monsieur Lange(1936) and the popularity of pacifism and appeasement in La Grande Illusion (1937). With the death of Jean Vigo and the exile of Rene Clair, Renoir was by the end of the decade the best director in France, producing on the eve of war his masterpiece La Regle du Jeu, a memorable portrait of a leisured class whose days were numbered.  Renoir began work on it immediately after the Munich agreement intending to portray a society that was “gnawed by a malady and dancing on a volcano”. Required Class Reading:Keith Reader, La Regle du Jeu (2010)Suggested Reading:Phil Powrie and Keith Reader, French cinema: a student's guide (2002)Martin O’Shaughnessy, Jean Renoir (2000)Colin Davis, Postwar Renoir: Film & the Memory of Violence (2012)Dudley Andrew, Mists of Regret: Culture and sensibility in classic French film (1995)Jill Forbes, Enfants du Paradis (1997)Julian Jackson, La Grande Illusion (BFI Film Classics, 2009)Andrew Dudley and Steven Ungar, Popular Front Paris and the Poetics of Culture (2005).  Class 8 ~ Italian film and Fascism  ~ Colin Shindler and Eugenio BiaginiMain Film: Roma Citta Apertà (1945)Italian films made during the fascist period were usually not "fascist" in tone, although they were often nationalistic and patriotic, much like their Hollywood counterparts. Mussolini, like Hitler and Stalin, recognized the vital importance of film in shaping the opinions of the masses and Italian cinema in the 1930s and there were, predictably, a number of productions with heroic nationalist themes.   Political opposition to the fascists was fashionable at film schools but the search for realism in the Italian cinema began not with those men who became the neo-realists of the postwar period but, rather, with directors working in the 1930s and the 1940s before the end of World War II. In an important manifesto published in 1933 a pro-Mussolini journalist called for Italian directors to take their cameras into the streets and to produce a non-Hollywood version of Italian everyday life. However, since Italian films were not exported abroad few Italian films of the interwar years have survived to be examined for such innovation. An exception is Luchino Visconti’s first film Ossessione, an adaptation of James M. Cain’s thriller The Postman Always Rings Twice, in which the influence of Renoir is unmistakably present. He had worked as 3rd assistant director on Renoir’s Une Partie de Campagne (1936) and it was the French director who sent Visconti a translation of the Cain book. The battles with the fascist censors were unending but eventually the film was made and contains some astonishingly frank depictions of adultery. Rossellini’s Roma Citta Apertà, co-written with Fellini, was made as German snipers remained in the streets of Rome after the invading Allied armies had liberated the city. The documentary, neo-realist nature of the film made it instantly famous and set the tone for the postwar decade of films by de Sica, Fellini, Visconti and Rossellini which are commonly regarded as a high watermark in Italian cinema, and as benchmarks for a new direction in world cinema.  Required Class Reading:David Forgacs, Rome Open City (BFI, 2000)Suggested Reading:Peter Bondanella, A History of Italian Cinema (2010)Angela Dalle Vacche, The Body in the Mirror: Shapes of History in Italian Cinema (1992)Paul Ginsborg, A History of Contemporary Italy, 1943-1980 (1990) chs 1-3 [google]Stuart Woolf, The Rebirth of Italy, 1943-1950 (1972)David Forgacs, Italian Culture in the Industrial Era 1880-1980: Cultural Industries, Politics and the Public (1990)J. Hay, Popular Film Culture in Fascist Italy (1987)Marcia Landy, Italian Film (2000)Pierre Sorlin, Italian National Cinema 1896-1996 (1996) © 2017 University of Cambridge

web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at Cambridge Virtually everyone in the past, as now, worked for their living. Discovering how the words ‘work’ and ‘labour’ were used historically helps to   understand how these words are used in so many different contexts today. (Think of housework, in work, and needlework, or labourer and   being in labour.). Examining what kinds of work people did allows us to glimpse how different their daily lives were from our own, and also to assess processes of economic development in the long run. Covering five and a half centuries, between the poll tax of 1377 and the national census of 1911, we start with the endpoint because the early 20th century evidence is the most accessible to begin to understand the issues. Population lists like the poll tax and the census recorded occupations, which can be classified to determine the proportion of the population that worked in agriculture, in manufacturing, and in services. These three sectors are indicators of development for economists. But these sources more reliably recorded men’s occupations than they did women’s work. So we add other sources like account books to find out what work people were paid for. Formulaic sources like these which facilitate quantitative analysis are systematically contrasted with narrative sources providing qualitative discussions of work, including diaries, autobiographies, poetry and fiction. Throughout, close attention is paid to geography: from where in the country does the diarist or the quantitative source originate? Different types of landscape allow different types of economy which enables or limits ways of earning a living.Students taking this option will be using numerical material, but no knowledge of maths beyond basic numeracy is required. Training will be provided in the use of two software packages (MS Excel and MS Access) in the week before the option begins. Each chronological class is organised around this series of questions:(1)   What can the sources tell us about what ‘work’ meant?(2)   What proportion of men and women worked in agriculture, in manufacturing, and in services?(3)   Where were the most important clusters of nationally important economic activities?(4)   What regional differences were there?(5)   How specialised were individual occupations?(6)   What can we learn from these sources about how work varied across the life cycle?(7)   How did male and female patterns differ?(8)   How different are the above patterns from those we encountered in the previous class?(9)   What are strengths and limitations of the quantitative and qualitative evidence?(10)      What would like to know that the sources do not tell us?The classes are outlined below, along with their source material. Secondary reading lists and fuller class descriptions will be available on camtools for those taking this option. CLASS 0         Introduction to spreadsheets and databasesThe introductory session will teach students the basics of spreadsheet use with MS Excel and database use with MS Access, skills which they will use through the rest of the classes. Excel and Access are very widely used analytical packages with an unlimited range of applications outside of historical ones. CLASS 1         1851-1911: LABOURING LIVESThis class examines descriptive life histories of earning a living around the turn of the last century, in contrast to the quantitative census material. These are presented in types of narrative that we have seen before, like autobiography and investigators’ reports, and also in the form of reported speech, which echoes the seventeenth-century court records that we used in Class 2.Kitchen, F., Brother to the ox (1939)Sturt, G., Memoirs of a Surrey labourer (1907, reprinted 1978)Abram, A., ‘Newcastle’, in C. Black, ed., Married women’s work (1915, reprinted 1983)Pember Reeves, M., Round about a pound a week (1913, reprinted 1979), ‘Mothers’ days’Llewelyn Davies, M., ed., Life as we have known it (1933, reprinted 1977), ‘A plate-layer’s wife’ CLASS 2         1851-1911: NATIONAL CENSUSESThe national censuses from 1851 offer the most complete indication of occupational structure for women as well as men, at ten-year intervals. As of 2014, they are available in digital form. We will examine the ways that occupations have been classified, and in census material aggregated, over time, and the ways in which historians have used census data, focussing on the 1851, 1881 and 1911 censuses1911 Census of England and Wales, National and County Occupational Data, Males and Females1881 Census of England and Wales, Parish Occupational Data, Males and Females1851 Census of England and Wales, Parish Occupational Data, Males and Females CLASS 3         c1377-c1522: TAXATION RECORDS & DESCRIPTIONS OF WORKThe main aim of this session is to establish what occupations were carried out by ordinary men and women in the countryside and small towns in the late medieval period. A further specific aim is to determine how far the range and importance of occupations changed between the later fourteenth and early sixteenth centuries. Was the period c.1377-c.1520 one of structural change in the economy which gave rise to new occupations, including new occupations for women? We compare sources which permit quantification with qualitative sources. Two of the four primary sources for this class are taxation records, so we will investigate especially closely the strengths and weaknesses of this category of material. We also ask whether the communities documented in our selected sources are typical of the country as a whole.C.C. Fenwick, ed., The poll taxes of 1377, 1379 and 1381. Part 1Bedfordshire-Lincolnshire (British Academy Records of Social and Economic History, New Series 27, 1998), pp. 206-8 (Essex 1381 poll tax returns, Hinckford Hundred; Braintree, Bocking & Felsted)E.W. Stockton, ed., The Major Latin Works of John Gower (1962), pp. 208-11 (Gower’s Vox Clamantis (1378), Book 5 Chapters 9-11).J. Pound, ed., The Military Survey of 1522 for Babergh Hundred (Suffolk Records Society XXVIII, 1986), pp. 41-2, 75-82 (entries for Polstead and Lavenham)C.H. Williams, ed., English historical documents volume V: 1485-1558 (1967), pp. 192-201 (a description of England in an early Italian ‘relation’, c.1500)  CLASS 4         1550-1650: COURT RECORDS AND ACCOUNTS    With the creation of extensive legal systems in the later sixteenth century, court records survive detailing occupations; these relate both to prosecuted offences and to administrative matters like wills and inventories for inheritance purposes. Household account books also indicate who was paid for what goods or services, although account books’ survival is much patchier than court records because they rarely made it to an archive. With the advent of printing in England, Thomas Tusser published his guide to husbandry and housewifery (what we would call agriculture) and William Harrison described the social order.Tusser, T., An hundred good pointes of husbandry (1557) William Harrison, Description of England (1577 and 1587)Court depositions in Women’s worlds in seventeenth-century England, ed. P. Crawford and L. Gowing (2000)Business and household accounts of Joyce Jeffreys, 1638-48, ed. J. Spicksley (2012) CLASS 5         Essay guidance and review of databases for Class 6 CLASS 6          1650-1750: PARISH REGISTERS & TAX LISTINGSParish registers recorded baptisms, marriages and burials from the mid-sixteenth century.  Sometimes parish clerks noted the occupations of fathers (for baptisms), and the Occupational Structure project of the Cambridge Group for the History of Population & Social Structure has collected these data for 1100 parishes which consistently recorded male occupations in the period 1695-1730 (referred to as the c.1710 database). We will use Access and Excel in this class to analyse different geographical areas from the database. Baptismal registers do not record women’s occupations, but these do sometimes appear in tax listings, which record the occupations of household heads of both sexes.Data sets from the Occupational Structure Project: Parish register dataset  c.1710Tax listings: Bristol St Nicholas (1692), Denham (1749) CLASS 7          1650-1750: AUTOBIOGRAPHY, POETRY AND FICTIONThis period saw an exponential growth in print production. Autobiographical writing as we know it began in this period, both for private purposes and for the press. The novel appeared as a literary form for the first time in 1688 with Aphra Behn’s Oronooko, and reached full development with Daniel Defoe. Poetry acquired a mass market, and the stage was now open to women as well as men. All forms of writing were available to literate women and men -- as a way to make a living, as well as providing a means to write about making a living.Autobiography of William Stout of Lancaster (1665-1752), ed. J. Harland (1851)Daniel Defoe,   A Tour Through the Whole Island of Britain (1722)Daniel Defoe, Col. Jack and Moll Flanders (both 1722)Stephen Duck, The thresher’s labour (1730)Mary Collier, The woman’s labour (1739)A Narrative of the life of Mrs Charlotte Charke (1755)  CLASS  8       1750-1850: PARISH REGISTERSFrom 1813, parish clerks were legally required to record the occupations of fathers of baptised children. The Occupational Structure project has collected these data from 11,400 parishes around the country, creating the first national survey available for this period. We will consider how the distribution of male occupations in the period 1813-20 differs from that which we saw for c.1710.Data set from the Occupational Structure Project:  1813-20 parish register data CLASS 9         1750-1850: INVESTIGATORS AND DIARISTSThis period sees the beginning of investigations into the problem of poverty on a national level, from individual surveys in the 1790s to the 1842 parliamentary enquiry into working conditions. These surveys sought explanations for dependence on poor relief or for high mortality, immorality or illiteracy. Personal memoirs including diaries and autobiographies written by the literate offer insight into the nature of work and the choices and constraints involved.David Davies, F.M. Eden and Robert Owen in G.D.H. Cole, ed., British working class movements; Select documents 1789-1875 (1965)1842 Parliamentary Enquiry: Report on the employment of young persons in Yorkshire coal minesThe diary of Thomas Turner 1754-1765, ed. D. Vaisey (1984)Journal of a governess 1807-11, ed. E. Hall (1936)The autobiography of Joseph Mayett of Quainton (1783-1839), ed. A. Kussmaul (1986)The wonderful adventures of Mrs Seacole in many lands (1858; reprinted 1984)              © 2017 University of Cambridge

        The Raven web authentication system is provided and managed by University Information Services.© 2017 University of CambridgeFaculty of HistoryStudying at Cambridge   How did a small band of determined men in North Africa manage to topple one of the most powerful European states? The Algerian War of Independence (1954-1962) split France and led to the creation of two new régimes: the French Fifth Republic in Europe and the People’s Democratic Republic of Algeria in North Africa. Without ever gaining control of Algerian territory, the Front de Libération Nationale (FLN) managed to win the war on the terrain of public opinion in Algeria, in the French metropole and on the world stage.This option allows students the opportunity to closely study one of the most iconic conflicts of the 20th century using a wide range of written, visual and audio sources in the original French. Students will be able to see for themselves how participants in the Algerian War of Independence captured the public’s attention using propaganda films, radio broadcasts, spectacular acts of violence, posters and public speeches.A prior knowledge of French is required for this course, and students will receive additional language classes to help read the sources. The option is designed to bring students with A2 or AS-level French up to a level where they will be able to work with a range of primary and secondary source material in French. Primary source material will be in French, and secondary reading will draw on recent cutting-edge research in both French and English. The language component of the course will be taught by Dr Anne-Laure Brevet.French propaganda poster, 1959, Archives Nationales d'Outre-Mer, 9Fi344 Introductory reading:*Gillo Pontecorvo, Battle of Algiers (1966), [film, 120 mins.]*Sylvie Thénault, Histoire de la guerre d’indépendance algérienne, Paris, 2005.*Todd Shepard, The Invention of Decolonization: The Algerian War and the Remaking of France, Ithaca, 2006.*James McDougall, A History of Algeria, Cambridge, 2017.*Matthew Connelly, A Diplomatic Revolution: Algeria’s Fight for Independence and the Origins of the Post-Cold War Era, Oxford, 2002.Martin Evans, Algeria: France’s Undeclared War, Oxford, 2011.Thénault, Peyroulou, Bouchène and Siari Tengour (eds.), Histoire de l’Algérie à la période coloniale, Paris/Algiers, 2012.Mohammed Harbi, Le FLN, mirage et réalité des origines à la prise du pouvoir (1945-1962), Paris, 1980.Benjamin Stora, La gangrène et l’oubli: la mémoire de la guerre d’Algérie, Paris, 1998. Week 1: A Part of France? c.1945-1954This class establishes the background to the war by looking back at France’s long colonial rule in Algeria, which was declared part of French territory in 1848. What did it mean to say Algeria was a part of France, and how was this claim contested by Algerian nationalist movements? Week 2: Revolution! The FLN’s Insurrection 1954-58Starting with the attacks on 1 November 1954, the FLN was able in a few years to impress, scare or cajole a wide swathe of the Algerian population into supporting it, defeating rival nationalist movements and gaining widespread international recognition as the legitimate representative of the Algerian people. This session will look at how the FLN deployed spectacular acts of violence, careful propaganda, and diplomatic activity to grab attention and spread its revolutionary agenda. Week 3: Counter-Insurgency, 1956-1960This session examines the French response to the FLN’s insurrection. From 1956, successive governments oversaw a massive escalation of the French presence in Algeria that combined military action with the increased provision of social services. How did French governments try to gain the support of the majority of the Algerian population, as well as convincing the rest of the world that French rule in North Africa was legitimate? Week 4: Affairs and Controversies This session looks at the changing nature of metropolitan public opinion on the war, by focusing on a number of high-profile controversies that splashed the covers of the French press, from the French army’s use of torture to investigations into conditions in detention camps. How did shifting media coverage and censorship affect what the French public understood violence in Algeria? Week 5: Symbols of Liberation – Women in the War:Neither the French government nor the FLN gave Algerian women much effective political power, but both used images of women extensively to claim that they represented all of Algeria. While the French government argued that France was emancipating Algerian women from a retrograde Islamist movement, the FLN put its revolutionary female fighters at the forefront of its international image. This session explores why gendered representations were so important to both sides’ propaganda. Week 6: The French Civil War and The OAS, 1958-1962This session looks at the emergence of a new player in the war: the Organisation Armée Secrète (OAS), a militant organisation of French settlers that entered into violent conflict with both the French government and the FLN. How did the settlers try to mobilise the attention of the metropolitan public against the French government? At first they did so successfully, in the May 1958 that ended the Fourth Republic, and then unsuccessfully, through the failed coup of 1961 and the formation of the violent Organisation Armée Secrète (OAS). Week 7: 1962 - A Very Violent Peace This session examines the cataclysmic ‘end’ of the conflict in 1962. Why was that it was after the French government and the FLN signed a peace agreement in March 1962 that some of the worst violence erupted? We will look at how both sides tried to project images of peace and negotiation in spite of mounting violence and displacement, as the triumphant independence of Algeria in July 1962 was set against the backdrop of mass settler exodus and civil war among the FLN leadership. Week 8: Memory Wars Did the war to control public opinion ever really end? Issues of legitimacy and representation of the conflict are still very much up for grabs among both historians and politicians. This session looks at a number of controversies over the war years on both sides of the Mediterranean up to the present day, including debates about the role of torture in the French army, arguments about the place of the FLN as the founder of the Algerian nation, and alleged connections between the war and racial relations in France today. Bibliography © 2017 University of Cambridge

web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at CambridgeThis option offers an introduction to the principal texts of ‘sacred history’ in the Judaeo-Christian traditions.  It is intended, first of all, to enable you to get to grips with the Bible and other related sources as works of history.  Historiography, or the history of historical writing, is usually studied through civil and secular historical writing, beginning with the Greek historians; an outline of this tradition is provided through HAP lectures.  This paper will focus on the no less important tradition of sacred historical writing, concerning God’s relations with his peoples.  It begins from the Bible, in both its Jewish and its Christian forms; within the Bible, the focus will be on those parts which are in some sense historical narratives.  An essential preliminary will be an introduction to the history of the texts themselves – their composition and dating, their possible basis in oral tradition – and the formation of the canon in both Hebrew and Christian Bibles.  But the focus will be historiographical, and the Bible histories will be set off against and compared with the major other accounts of the same sacred-historical material, Josephus’s Jewish histories and Eusebius’ history of the Church.  Connected with the historiographical purpose, a secondary object of the paper will be to explore the political thought of sacred history: the concepts which informed sacred history’s treatments of the earliest forms of society, of the emergence of the Hebrews as a nation, of the development of their forms of government, and of the later relations of the Christian Church with Roman authority.  The paper will not be concerned with the religious truth or theological interpretation of the sacred texts, though it is important to appreciate the theological frameworks in which they were written. The introductory character of the paper determines the choice of texts, deliberately limited to major works in both Jewish and Christian traditions.  Alongside the Hebrew and Christian Bibles, Josephus provides histories written in ‘classical’ form, while Eusebius offers the foremost example of the ‘new’ ecclesiastical history developed by the early Christians.  In addition there are shorter selections from the principal commentators in each tradition, Maimonides and Augustine.  The inclusion of chapters from Gibbon provides a later counter-point to Eusebius; in important respects Gibbon was heir to the Eusebian tradition of Christian sacred history, as well as one of its greatest critics.Although there will be library copies, it is desirable to acquire your own copies of the main texts; possession of these will enable you to range more widely that the restricted selection of prescribed passages.  All the main texts are ones which you can expect to keep and refer to long after you have graduated. The class programme is given below.  The reading for each class and a comprehensive Bibliography will be available on the Moodle website.  Possible extended essay topics are listed separately.For those who are interested, it may be possible to develop comparisons with Islamic sacred history on the basis of secondary literature; likewise the material covered in the course will be an excellent basis for study of sacred historical writing in the medieval and early modern periods. Prescribed TextsThe Hebrew Bible – The Old TestamentBooks of Genesis, Exodus (1-20), I Samuel, I Kings (1-11), Daniel, Ezra:in The Jewish Study Bible – Tanakh Translation, ed A. web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at CambridgeIn 1955, leaders of the newly independent states of Africa, Asia and the Middle East gathered in Bandung in Indonesia for a conference which they hoped would mark the beginning of a new world order.  Twenty-nine countries were present, representing over 1.3 billion people, a majority of the world’s population at the time. This course takes the 'Bandung moment' as a starting point from which to explore the theme of anti-imperialist thought and action and Afro-Asian solidarity in the global history of the twentieth century.Anti-imperialist thought and practice in the twentieth century took on a variety of guises, in terms of its ideological underpinnings, modes of expression and ultimate aims, and is therefore ideally suited to comparative analysis. To this end, we consider anti-imperialist thought from a series of angles: revolution and violence, socialism and economic thinking, religion, culture and universal human rights, with an eye to comparisons and connections across time and space. Running through all of the classes will be an interrogation of competing ideas of freedom, its meaning and the best path towards its realization.This course offers an introduction to global and transnational history and to the regional histories of Africa, Asia and the Middle East. It will take advantage of recent literature on the Bandung conference itself as a foundational moment in the making of the post-colonial world as well as a host of recent studies of the intellectual, cultural and social history of anti-imperialism, approached through a transnational framework of analysis. There is a wealth of source material available in English and in translation which will both provide the basis for class discussions and provide extremely rich opportunities for Long Essay projects. The published and unpublished writings and speeches of revolutionaries, intellectuals, politicians, officials and journalists will form the major body of source material, but use will also be made of images and film.Preliminary reading:* Roeslan Abdulgani, The Bandung Connection: The Asia-Africa Conference in Bandung in 1955, Singapore: Gunung Agung, 1981* George McTurnan Kahin, The Asian-African Conference: Bandung, Indonesia, April 1955. Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1956.* Richard Wright, The Colour Curtain: A Report on the Bandung Conference, 1956Cemil Aydin, The Politics of Anti-Westernism in Asia: Visions of World Order in Pan-Islamic and Pan-Asianthought, Columbia Unviersity Press, New York, 2007Christoper J. Lee, Making a World After Empire: The Bandung Moment and its Political Afterlives, Ohio University Press, 2010Rudolf Mrazek, A certain age: colonial Jakarta through the memories of its intellectuals, Durham NC: Duke University Press, 2010Vijay Prashad, The Darker Nations: A People’s History of the Third World, New York: The New Press, 2007Class 1: A Conference at BandungThis class examines the national revolution in Indonesia in 1945 and its global impact. The leaders of the new republic appealed directly to the international community. Its first prime minister, the westernised socialist, Sutan Sjahrir, took Indonesia’s cause to the United Nations. Its first president, Sukarno, unleashed a more charismatic, populist appeal to what he termed, the ‘New Emerging Forces’. This class examines the Bandung Conference of 1955 against the political thinking of the Indonesian revolution. Its international networks were complex and of long duration. It was characterised by attempts to reconcile different ideological traditions, such as in the thought of Tan Malaka, a prophet of a new ‘Aslia’; in the synthetic ‘Nasakom’ (nationalism, Islam, Communism) of Sukarno, and the socialist internationalism of Sjahrir. The class examines the precursors and planning of the 1955 Bandung conference; the role of powers such as India and China; its ideas and forms of diplomacy, and the birth of non-alignment. Was Bandung a gathering of nation-states rather than a movement of peoples? What was its imaginative purchase across the global South?Class 2: Precursors to Bandung: the roots of revolution and anti-imperialism inAfrica and AsiaBy the end of the First World War, anti-imperialist and revolutionary movements in the colonial world had begun to use new networks and to seek  new constituents, both nationally and internationally. In February of 1927, Jawaharlal Nehru attended the Congress of Oppressed Nationalities in  Brussels on behalf of the Indian National Congress. Delegates from 37 colonised countries met alongside supporters from Europe and the U.S. In a speech to the Brussels Congress often cited as a harbinger of non-alignment, Nehru argued that ‘the great problem of the near future will be American imperialism, even more than British imperialism. Or, it may be, and all indications point to it, that the two will join together to create a powerful Anglo-Saxon bloc to dominate the world.’ Speaking on U.S. imperialism in Latin America, Nehru emphasised the shared struggle of colonized and oppressed people around the world, and the necessity of working together to overcome imperialism. At the same Congress, he was elected to the Executive Council of the League Against Imperialism, (Ligue contre l’imperialisme et l'oppression colonial) an organisation affiliated with Comintern which aimed to establish itself as a League of Nations for the colonized world. Later that year, he attended the tenth anniversary celebration of the October revolution in Moscow. Also in 1927, the fourth Pan-African Congress met in Harlem, New York, addressing concerns about racialised oppression and violence in Anglophone Africa and the U.S., the drain of resources from African colonies by European colonial powers, and the necessity for accountable governance and home rule in West Africa and the West Indies. And in the same year the Ligue de defense de la race Negre, newly under Afro-Caribbean leadership, called in La Race Negre for the collaboration between Francophone black intellectuals and workers, and a student-led Pan-Africanism. How can we explain the remarkable explosion and convergence of global anti-imperial movements during the 1920s? And how did such movements influence postcolonial internationalism? This class explores the pre-history of Bandung by focussing on revolutionary and anti-imperial movements in colonial India, Africa, and Indonesia between 1917 and 1940, looking at how anti-imperial movements began to take on revolutionary aims and to formalise international partnerships.Class 3: Human RightsIn his account of the Bandung Conference, the Lebanese diplomat and philosopher, and former member of the commission which drafted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Charles Malik, wrote that: ‘One of the basic issues on which we were sharply divided… was the question of Human Rights. What are the ultimate fundamental Human Rights? For the Communists these rights are for the most part social and economic rights; but for some of the rest of us the ultimate human rights that should now be guaranteed by the world and by the diverse nations are the personal, legal, political rights to freedom’. This class explores the theme of human rights in the history of anti-imperialist thought, engaging with recent literature on the role of human rights in decolonization. For the historian Samuel Moyn, anti-imperialism and decolonization had nothing to do with human rights. In contrast, for Roland Burke, human rights were at the centre of the decolonization process. In this class, we will explore this debate by looking at the competing ways in which human rights were conceptualised in the colonial world, both at the Bandung conference itself and in wider traditions of anti-imperial thought. Was it possible to have a universal conception of human rights? What was the relationship between individual human rights and rights to national self-determination, and how did this relationship change between the 1940s and the 1960s? Did freedom lie in protecting political rights or in the fulfilment of social and economic rights? How might conceptions of duty be integrated into a theory of human rights?Class 4: Violence and RevolutionThe ‘Bandung moment’ was a tumultuous time across much of the colonial world. While some territories, such as the Gold Coast/Ghana, Senegal, Morocco, and Tunisia, witnessed a relatively peaceful transition of power from Britain and France to the newly anointed leaders of independent states, others descended into a violent cycle of insurgency and counter-insurgency. This was the case in British Malaya, Kenya, and Cyprus, where the British declared ‘emergencies’, introducing a swathe of repressive measures in an attempt to quell local contestation, and in Algeria, whose brutal war of independence, which lasted from 1954 to 1962, threatened the very stability of the French Republic.In this class, we will look at a number of writings which examined the intimate relationship between colonialism and violence, and asked whether violence might serve to put an end to colonialism and forge a new world order. We will focus in particular on a number of writers from France and its empire who analysed, and criticised, the various forms of violence – both psychological and physical – that characterised what the French scholar Georges Balandier christened the ‘colonial situation’. These range from the existentialist philosopher and engaged intellectual Jean-Paul Sartre, to the poet and Communist deputy for Martinique Aimé Césaire, the Tunisian Jewish novelist Albert Memmi, and the Martiniquais psychiatrist Frantz Fanon, who experienced the violence of colonialism first hand while working in Algeria. All published stinging rebukes to colonialism in the 1950s and early 1960s, which chronicled the considerable violence of colonial rule, and suggested ways to overturn imperialism. What political events led them to write these, and how did their intellectual formations and lived experiences influence their arguments? How typical were their arguments, and what claims did those who disagreed with them make? How did they influence debate in France, and further afield, in the immediate wake of their publication? And how have they been read and understood in the decades since Bandung?Class 5: SocialismFrom the beginning of the twentieth century, critics of imperialism argued that imperialism was fundamentally an economic phenomenon which drained wealth from the colonised world to the West. Regaining economic independence was a central element of anti-imperial thinking. And for many, it seemed axiomatic that capitalism itself was at fault, serving metropolitan economies but not the needs of colonial peoples. But if some form of socialism was the route to economic prosperity based on equality and economic justice, what should that socialism look like? How might an Arab, Indian or an African socialism differ from Western traditions of socialist thought? In the era of the Cold War, how could leaders navigate a path that allowed them to pursue economic justice and employ a global language of socialism while pursuing a political course of non-alignment between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R.? Should newly independent countries turn to the U.S. or the U.S.S.R for technical expertise or instead seek to exchange ideas and build connections across the post-colonial world? In this class, we look at a range of thinkers from across the Afro-Asian world, the roots of their socialist thought and the different types of socialism they proposed.Class 6: Islamist anti-imperialismThis class will examine the broad phenomenon of Islamist anti-imperialism across Africa, Asia and the Middle East. It will focus on the diverse ideologies that make up Islamist anti-imperialist thought, look at the manner in which these ideas are articulated in various contexts, and discuss the aims of Islamist anti-imperialist thinkers and activists. Central to these ideas are the construction of alternative Islamic political geographies and frameworks that would be implemented once freedom from imperialist rule had been won. Islamist anti-imperialism had its roots in the nineteenth century, and played a key role in many revolts and broader anti-imperial movements during the twentieth century. This class will consider how existing binaries between Islamists vs. Europe/‘the West’ can be nuanced through discussing case studies from the Ottoman Empire, Africa, and the secular empire of the Soviet Union.Class 7: Language and CultureThis class explores anti-imperialist thought in the domain of culture. Many anti-imperialist thinkers agreed that culture was a central battle ground in the fight against colonialism. But where they disagreed was on the form which cultural independence should take. In this class, we will read the writings of a number of those who reflected on what cultural independence might mean. For Léopold Senghor and Aimé Césaire, the philosophy of négritude, developed in Paris in the 1920s and 1930s offered a way of reclaiming cultural authenticity through a new articulation of black identity, but for others négritude seemed to accept the negative stereotypes which had legitimised colonialism. The question of language also prompted lively debate. Did using colonial languages mean accepting colonial or neo-colonial domination or not? For the Nigerian writer Chinua Achebe, colonial languages could be turned to anti-colonial ends, while the Kenyan novelist Ngugi wa Thiong’o rejected English in favour of the Kikuyu language. We look at the origins of these debates in the intellectual culture of the 1930s, and consider how they were reworked in the era of decolonization.Class 8: Legacies of BandungThis class will explore the political, diplomatic, intellectual and cultural legacies of the ‘Bandung moment’.© 2017 University of Cambridge

web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at CambridgeThemes and Sources is examined via a Long Essay of 3,000 to 5,000 words.  This is a ‘take-home’ examination paper which first-year students receive in May, after they have completed the course.  Students submit their Long Essay the following January, at the start of the Lent term in their second year.  The aims of the Long Essay are to test students’ understanding of the main problems and approaches of the course they have followed with reference to a specific question.The paper is usually divided into two parts.  Students are required to answer one question specified in the paper for their option, from either section A) Essay questions, or section B) Topics. Section A contains specific, targeted questions whose wording may not be altered.  Section B outlines broad topics within which a student could devise a more precise title, in consultation with the teacher of the option, who must formally approve the final title.  Option teachers must ensure that the title eventually chosen relates to the overall issues developed by the option, and that there is adequate source material and secondary literature available to the student.Skills ExaminedThe basic skills to be tested are similar to those expected in a supervision essay: the ability to argue clearly and cogently; to expound the issues involved in a given topic or problem; to evaluate interpretations and their relevance to the evidence on which historical argument is based.  Essays may vary in the extent of their treatment of historiography depending on the approaches of individual options, but because many Themes and Sources options focus particularly on primary source material, students are expected, where possible, to pay special attention to evaluating sources, e.g. by discussing and comparing their reliability and explaining their value for the historian. Sophisticated discussion of such matters raised by a question or topic may constitute the main contents of an essay.  However, in other cases students may be expected to concentrate more on secondary literature; advice will be given about the most suitable course of action appropriate to each essay title.  In addition, students should show ability to use footnotes and to present an adequate bibliography of the sources and literature used.The Long Essay provides the opportunity for students to show how well they have grasped the general issues raised by the option and their ability to analyse them in terms of a particular historical problem.  It can often be written using the materials provided in the source books (or similar source material indicated by option teachers) and supplemented by secondary reading.  Again, more precise guidance on this point will be given in individual options.  Students may be expected to show some initiative in finding and identifying literature on their subject, but the option teachers will provide sufficient material to make a start.The marking criteria for assessment of Themes and Sources Long Essays are available here (see p.5).Writing the Long EssayDuring the Easter Term there will be a ninth class and an individual supervision of 30-45 minutes (which will be arranged with one of the class teachers) devoted to discussing the requisite content, research methods, and format of the Long Essay, amongst other general issues.  The supervision is also an opportunity to discuss the nature of a question and its relation to the overall option theme, as well as bibliography, and for the teacher to give more general advice concerning structure and presentation.  Students should give careful thought to the choice of questions before the supervision and if possible narrow down their choice to one or two questions or topics.  Students are also advised to look at some of the reading in advance, so as to make best use of the supervision.Students should note that as this is an examination paper, this is the only individual tuition permitted and no further supervision is provided during the course of their work on the Long Essay. It is permissible to approach option teachers to ask for further bibliographical advice at a later stage, but they will not provide further supervision, read drafts or give further advice concerning the content of an essay.  In the interests of equity and to preserve the integrity of the examination, Directors of Studies have no involvement in the preparation of the Long Essay.  While they may assist in planning of work schedules, they must on no account be approached to discuss content or to read or comment on drafts of the Long Essay, nor is it permissible to ask other teachers or graduate students to do so.It should be emphasised that the bulk of the work necessary for this paper must be done during the LONG VACATION.  Because of difficulties of access to libraries during that time, a lengthy period has been allowed for completion and submission of the Long Essay.  Students should plan their work carefully in advance so that some preliminary work is done before going down for the Long Vacation and so that a final draft is ready before coming up for the Michaelmas Term in the second year.  The Christmas vacation should only be used for final corrections and adjustments, so that a completed and revised essay can be submitted at the beginning of the Lent Term.The Faculty Style Guide (available on the website) gives detailed guidance about word count, presentation, footnotes and bibliography, and is essential reading.Submission of Long EssaysThe Long Essay must be submitted to the Themes and Sources Secretary in the History Faculty by 3.30pm on the first Thursday of Lent Full Term.Late submission will only be granted in exceptional circumstances. Your College must apply to the Secretary of the Applications Committee for an extension to a deadline and should not approach the Chair of Examiners directly. Any extension will be for a specified period. Applications must be made in reasonable time to enable the Secretary to consult the Chair.  An essay submitted later than the date specified by the Chair of Examiners, or by the due date if no extension has been granted, will not be accepted  (University Ordinances, Chapter III, Section 2, Regulation 7 refers). Students are required to submit TWO hard copies and ONE digital copy of their Long Essay, on the day that the essay is due.  All copies of the Long Essay must be typed, unless permission to the contrary has been granted in advance by the Themes and Sources Convenor, which will only happen in exceptional cases.A completed Cover Sheet should be stapled or securely attached to the front of each hard copy of the Long Essay, ensuring that all information is clearly legible.  The full title of the essay should be repeated at the top of the first page of all copies, and particular attention should be paid to any supplementary rubric at the top of individual option papers.Students are required to submit the digital copy of their Long Essay to Turnitin UK via Moodle, the content of which must be identical with that of the hard copies.  Further instructions for the digital submission will be issued prior to the submission date.  Turnitin UK text-matching software is an online service that compares submitted work for matches with a database of material available online and with a ‘private’ database of previous submissions.  Twenty percent of each submission will be selected for scrutiny by the Academic Secretary, acting as Faculty Academic Integrity Officer.  Normally, this will be work highlighted by the Turnitin software as containing a significant amount of recognised text. Work recommended by Examiners for further investigation may also be selected for scrutiny. Originality reports for scrutinised work will be referred to the Examiners responsible for the academic assessment of the work if there is prima facie evidence of plagiarism or poor academic practice.Students will be asked to confirm their awareness of this process on a separate (unbound) Declaration form, which is to be handed-in at the time of submission.  Identifying information must not appear anywhere other than on this form.  The Declaration contains a statement about plagiarism, which is the unacknowledged use of the work of others as if it were original work.  All material must be fully referenced and acknowledged.  Plagiarism is a serious offence and will not be tolerated by the Faculty of History.  Further information about the Faculty’s use of Turnitin and how to avoid plagiarism, can be found on the Faculty website: Guidance on Plagiarism.  The University also publishes detailed guidance here: http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/univ/plagiarism/students/Students are reminded to take care of their work and to back-up text, keep extra copies separately etc.  Students, and not the Faculty, are responsible for submitting their essays on time.  Computer difficulties, stolen equipment, failure to allow sufficient time for printing problems etc. will not be accepted as excusable reasons for late submission.Finally, please note that the essay will not be returned after the completion of the class list, but will be retained by the Board of Examiners for 6 months like any other examination script.  If students wish to keep a copy for their own purposes, they should bear this in mind before submitting the essay.Related contentHistory Faculty Style Guide © 2017 University of Cambridge

web browser if you wish but then our site may not work correctly.Faculty of HistoryStudying at CambridgeOutlineThis Themes and Sources option focuses upon poverty and wealth, relative and absolute, at two deeply interrelated levels. At micro level we ask how individuals and households worked to survive and thrive in the context of the shifting sets of material resources and social and political relations with which they lived and, in some cases, sought to change. At macro level we examine the political economy of accumulation and development. The general aims of the course are to introduce the major themes and debates in the economic history of West Africa, from the slave trades to the present, and, equally, to encourage students to sample a wide range of different kinds of sources, quantitative and qualitative, used by economic historians of Africa and other regions of the Global South. Students are invited to develop a sense of the region and period as a whole, but within that to focus their own reading (and watching) of primary sources on selected themes and cases. No previous training is required in African history or economics, and the level of maths needed is basic numeracy. Again, the only language required is English. If you can read French, you will have the option in a couple of classes of choosing a French source instead of an English-language one.Preliminary readingHopkins, A. G., An Economic History of West Africa (London: Longman, 1973).Iliffe, John, The African Poor: A History (Cambridge 1987).Class 1. Introduction: Wealth and Poverty in West African HistoryThis session briefly introduces:a) The region: its changing environmental and human characteristics over the last three centuries, including its long history of extra-subsistence, market-oriented economic activity, and, until the late twentieth century, a relatively high ratio of land (albeit often of fragile fertility) to labour.b) The debates, especially about the historical origins of (West) Africa’s relative poverty today: institutional, resource-based and cultural explanations offered by rival schools, and ‘internalist’ versus ‘externalist’ approaches.c) The primary sources, qualitative and quantitative: their problems and potential.Primary sourcesLevtzion, N., and J.E.P. Commercial, Political and Labour Transformations, 1804/7--c.1929We consider the interconnections between three fundamental transitions:a) From the export of slaves to export agriculture (‘legitimate commerce’): this began during the gradual decline of the Atlantic slave trade from West Africa (from 1807) and was intensified during the early colonial period, still often at the initiative of African entrepreneurs.b) From the formation of new Islamic states, notably the Sokoto Caliphate (1804) to the European colonization of West Africa, mainly during the ‘Scramble’ of 1879-c.1903. Some African entrepreneurs expected that colonial rule would make it easier for them to make and keep wealth.c) From slave to wage labour within the region: but prefaced by an expansion of slave-holding, supplying labour for cash-crop production, before the colonization; after which most European administrations proceeded to take a very gradual approach to implementing their promise to abolish slavery.Primary sourcesWilks, Ivor, ‘Dissidence in Asante Politics: two tracts from the late nineteenth century’, in Wilks, Forests of Gold, pp. 169-88 (‘lightly revised’ from a 1975 publication). Economic Discontents, Hopes, and ‘Development’ under Middle and Late Colonialism, 1929-1960We discuss different strands of economic unhappiness, some of which were profound but largely beneath the surface of the political conflict of the era (notably struggles over the gender division of work and its rewards in household and community contexts), while others were much more visible to both African politicians and colonial administrations, because they challenged the domination of much of the economy by private European monopolies, the practices of colonial governments, and eventually colonial rule itself. Relatedly, and partly in specaific response to some of the mass discontents, an increasingly strong tendency emerged for states to be more active than before, both in seeking and spending revenue, often in the name of ‘development’, While our focus will be on what was happening within West Africa, it is important to take account of the international contexts, notably the trends in the world market for African primary products (adverse during the world depression and Second World War, much more positive in the 1950s) and the increasing critical pressures on the policies and principle of colonial rule, especially after 1945.Primary sourcesTete-Ansá, W., Africa at Work (New York: self-published, 1930), pp. 63, 68-73, 78-87.Meyer Fortes Papers from the Ashanti Social Survey (in Cambridge University Library):  a selection of copies of papers from file of widows’ testimonies, c.1945.Government correspondence on the Nigerian ‘General Strike’ of July 1945, in Martin Lynn (ed.), Nigeria, Part I, Managing Political Reform 1943-1953 (British Documents on the End of Empire, Series B, Volume 7) (London: Stationery Office, 2001), pp. 50-59.Central Office of Information, United Kingdom, Here is the Gold Coast (1947), www.youtube.com/watch?v=IlDSHqVhPZE  A 35-minute official film on poverty and development expenditure. Secondary sourcesFor general reference and broader contexts: John Iliffe, Africans: The History of a Continent (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2nd edition, 2007), pp. 219-72.Miles, John, ‘Rural protest in the Gold Coast: the cocoa hold-ups, 1908-1938’, in Clive Dewey and A. Living Standards, Demographic and Structural Change under Colonial RuleThe beginning of West Africa’s transition from labour-scarcity to labour-surplus can be timed from the aftermath of the world influenza pandemic of 1918, since when the population has risen continuously, including probably a doubling by the end of colonial rule c.1960. Stimulated by colonial and African investments in improving transport, the growth of agricultural export economies entailed a degree of urbanization. Meanwhile, living standards varied considerably between different ecological zones: the cocoa-growing areas of southern Ghana and southwest Nigeria, and even the coastal, groundnut-exporting parts of Senegal and the Gambia, offered much more reward for farmers than the more isolated parts of the savanna, still less in the Sahel. Economic historians have focussed on comparing the real wages and other measures of living standards in non-settler economies (which comprised most of West Africa) with the settler and plantation colonies of much of central and southern Africa. While British West Africa, especially, does well in that comparison, its record was very unimpressive for the growth of manufacturing industry. Let us examine the strengths and weaknesses of the sources available on all these topics, and consider the uses and limits of the methods applied to them. As a primary-source case-study, we consider two pioneering quantitative studies from colonial Ghana. Cardinall was the Gold Coast Census Officer, and made an effort to estimate many things, including what we would now call GDP per capita.Primary sourcesCardinall, A. Political Economy of Ghana: From Independence to Economic Liberalization, 1957-83Ghana has rightly been called ‘the perennial test-case’. It was the first country in West Africa to achieve independence from colonial rule (1957), under the charismatic leadership of Kwame Nkrumah, who took the economy on an increasingly state-led development path. By 1983 it had become the proverbial ‘basket case’, with an inexorably shrinking economy accompanied by multiple coups. Then a left-wing populist ‘revolutionary’ government, led by J. J. Rawlings, felt obliged to  reverse the policy trend of itself and its predecessors, and embark on systematic economic liberalization, in conjunction with loans from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Ghana became the most successful of the few conspicuously successful cases of ‘Structural Adjustment’ in Africa, with its economy growing by about 5% a year on average to the present. Rawlings held elections in 1992 under a new constitution. He won, but since then there have been two occasions on which the ruling party handed over power after election defeat. That never happened during the period we study, which includes Ghana’s first three republics, three conventional military regimes, and two Rawlings ‘revolutions’. We ask: how and why did this relatively prosperous newly-independent economy, then the world’s leading exporter of cocoa beans, fall into economic stagnation and then absolute decline by the late 1970s? By the early 1980s, the leading rational-choice political scientist of Africa, Robert Bates, was arguing that most post-colonial governments were essentially urban coalitions interested only in rewarding their own supporters and relaxed about the fate of the economy as a whole. Yet Rawlings’ government did reverse policy: why, and how did it succeed, if this was against the urban interests that supported it?Broadcasts and speeches by heads of statePresident Kwame Nkrumah, Dawn Broadcast, 8 April 1961. 10 pp.Colonel I. Poverty and Wealth in Post-Independence West AfricaIt is arguable that since independence West Africa, like Sub-Saharan or at least tropical Africa as a whole, has seen one watershed in economic policy, and two in economic performance. The 1960s and 1970s saw, on the whole, a continuation of the trend established in the late colonial period, for growing state intervention in the economy. This was drastically reversed by Structural Adjustment in the 1980s, which established the liberal economic regime which essentially prevails to this day.  Meanwhile, in most countries in the region, economic growth outpaced the continued growth of population until after the international oil price rise of 1973; then broadly stagnated until roughly 1995, since when the Sub-Saharan Africa economies, in aggregate, have apparently grown about 2% faster than the population; though manufacturing, as a share of output, actually shrank. In this section we will ask:a) How sure are we about this (or any alternative) summary of the trends of economic performance, given that there are major weaknesses in the national economic statistics?b) What other kinds of evidence, qualitative and quantitative, can we adduce on economic and social changes in post-independence West Africa, including on education, health, the relative importance of the ‘formal’ and ‘informal’ sectors of the economy? c) What can be said about changes in the motivation and capacity of states to facilitate economic (and broader human) development, including in the context of relations with foreign firms, states and international agencies? On this, we use the largest state in West Africa as a key case-study.‘Primary’ sourcesA selection of data series covering most of the period.World Bank, Accelerated Development in Sub-Saharan Africa: An Agenda for Action (Washington DC: World Bank, 1981). Pp. 1-16, 24-44. Widely known as the Berg Report, this was effectively the manifesto for Structural Adjustment in the 1980s.Secondary sourcesJerven, Morten, ‘What do we know about income and wealth in Africa?’, in his Poor Numbers: How We Are Misled by African Development Statistics and What to Do About it (Cornell University Press, 2013), pp. 8-32.Marwah, Hanaan, ‘What explains slow sub-Saharan African growth? Revisiting oil boom-era investment and productivity in Nigeria’s national accounts, 1976-85’, Economic History Review, 47:4 (2014), pp. 993-1011.Forrest, Tom, ‘The advance of African capital: the growth of Nigerian private enterprises’, in F. Stewart, S. Lall and S. Wangwe (eds), Alternative Development Strategies in Sub-Saharan Africa (Macmillan: London, 1992), pp. 368-401.
